{{COI|date=February 2017}}{{Infobox person | name = James Wesley, Rawles | image = | image_caption = James Wesley, Rawles, circa 2005 | birth_date = 1960 | birth_place = [[California]], United States | movement = [[American Redoubt]] (originator) | signature = Signature of James Wesley, Rawles.jpg | website = www.survivalblog.com | occupation = Novelist, nonfiction author, and blogger | education = Bachelor of Arts, [[San Jose State University]] }} '''James Wesley, Rawles''' (born 1960) is an American author, who writes [[survivalist]]-genre [[Patriots novel series]]. Rawles is a former [[United States Army|U.S. Army]] Intelligence officer. He is the founder and Senior Editor of SurvivalBlog.com, which covers survival and preparedness topics, and has published collected material from this in two books.<ref name="SP5-26-09" /> He also works as a [[retreat (survivalism)|survival retreat]] consultant.<ref name="SP5-26-09">{{cite web|author=Gillian Flaccus |url=http://www.spokesman.com/stories/2009/may/26/fears-spark-new-set-of-survivalists/ |title=Fears spark new set of survivalists |publisher=Spokesman.com |date=26 May 2009 |accessdate=21 February 2010}}</ref><ref name="Sara Nelson">{{cite web|author=Sara Nelson |url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/blogs-and-stories/2009-04-15/the-most-dangerous-novel-in-america/ |title=The Most Dangerous Novel in America? |publisher=The Daily Beast |date=15 April 2009 |accessdate=10 February 2012}}</ref><ref name="schuessler1">{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers-books/2011-10-23/hardcover-fiction/list.html | work=The New York Times | first=Jennifer | last=Schuessler | title=Print & E-Books}}</ref> Rawles is a [[Christian libertarianism|Constitutionalist Christian libertarian]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://survivalblog.com/about/ |title=What is SurvivalBlog? |publisher=SurvivalBlog.com |date=2011-08-24 |accessdate=2015-11-05}}</ref> On his book covers, in his signature, on his checks, in his blog, and as his legal name, he presents his name as "James Wesley, Rawles", using a comma to distinguish between his given and family names.<ref name="thedailybeast.com">{{cite web|author=Sara Nelson |url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/blogs-and-stories/2009-04-15/the-most-dangerous-novel-in-america/full/ |title=The Most Dangerous Novel in America? |publisher=The Daily Beast |date=15 April 2009 |accessdate=10 February 2012}}</ref>
==Early life and military career== James Wesley, Rawles was born James Wesley Rawles in [[California]] in 1960 and attended local public schools. He earned a [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree in Journalism from [[San Jose State University]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goodreads.com/author/show/7855159.James_Wesley_Rawles |title=James Wesley Rawles (Author of Patriots) |publisher=Goodreads.com |date= |accessdate=2015-11-05}}</ref>
From 1984 to 1993, he served as a [[United States Army]] [[Military Intelligence]] officer.<ref name=miobc>{{cite web|url=http://www.rawles.to/miobc/index.html |title=MIOBC Class 85-6 Virtual Reunion |publisher=Rawles.to |date= |accessdate=4 September 2013}}</ref> He resigned his commission as a U.S. Army [[Captain (United States O-3)|Captain]] immediately after [[Bill Clinton]] was inaugurated as President of the United States.<ref name=miobc/>
==Journalism and writing career== Rawles worked as an Associate Editor and Regional Editor (Western U.S.) with ''Defense Electronics'' magazine in the late 1980s and early 1990s<ref>''Defense Electronics'' magazine masthead (p. 7) – James W. Rawles, Associate Editor, EW Communications, Palo Alto, CA, August 1987 (Vol. 19, No. 8) to November 1988 (Vol. 20, No. 12);''Defense Electronics'' magazine masthead (p. 7) – James W. Rawles, Associate Editor, Cardiff Publishing, Englewood, CO. December 1988 (Vol. 20, No. 13) to September 1990 (Vol. 22, No. 9); ''Defense Electronics'' magazine masthead (p. 7) – James W. Rawles, Regional Editor (Western U.S.) Cardiff Publishing, Englewood, CO. October 1990 (Vol. 22, No. 10) to April 1991 (Vol. 23, No. 4); James W. Rawles, Associate Editor, EW Communications, Palo Alto, CA, January/February 1988 (Vol. 1 No. 1) to May/June 1988 (Vol. 1, No. 3)</ref> Concurrently he was Managing Editor of ''The International Countermeasures Handbook.''<ref>''The International Countermeasures Handbook'' (14th Edition, 1989). masthead (p. 388) James W. Rawles, Managing Editor</ref>
He worked as a technical writer through most of the 1990s with a variety of electronics and software companies, including [[Oracle Corporation]].<ref name=miobc /><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20090211124958/http://download-uk.oracle.com/docs/cd/A91202_01/901_doc/appdev.901/a89865/title.htm Pro*COBOL Precompiler]. download-uk.oracle.com. June 2001</ref> In 2005, he began blogging full-time.<ref name="SP5-26-09" /> He has since{{when|date=November 2018}} given up day-to-day blogging in order to devote more time to writing books.{{citation needed|date=November 2018}}
==Survivalism advocate== Rawles is now a freelance writer, blogger, and [[retreat (survivalism)|survival retreat]] consultant.<ref>{{cite web|author=Richard Cockle |url=http://www.oregonlive.com/news/index.ssf/2009/09/the_new_survivalists_oregon_pr.html |title=The new survivalists: Oregon 'preppers' stockpile guns and food in fear of calamity |publisher=OregonLive.com |date=5 September 2009 |accessdate=21 February 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5g7CZthQJEpoRBwaehT8jURHce5_w |title=AFP: Thought things were bad? US survivalists await worse |publisher=Google.com |date=30 January 2009 |accessdate=10 February 2012}}</ref> He was described as the "conscience of survivalism."<ref>Graham, Tim (27 April 2012) [https://web.archive.org/web/20120608085413/http://www.buffalonews.com/spotlight/article830941.ece 'Preppers': Ready for anything]. Buffalo News</ref> He is best known as the author of the survivalist novel ''[[Patriots: A Novel of Survival in the Coming Collapse]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.faz.net/s/Rub48A3E114E72543C4938ADBB2DCEE2108/Doc%7EE340491DBEDE94C4E9DF01F07365C1827%7EATpl%7EEcommon%7EScontent.html |title=Amerikanischer Bestseller: "Patriots": Wie das Ende unserer Welt zu überleben ist – Rezensionen |publisher=FAZ |date= |accessdate=10 February 2012}}</ref>
Rawles published a defense of his anti-racist views in a blog entry entitled "Race, Religion, and Reason" in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|title=Lest Any Man Should Boast: A Christian Survivalist Perspective on Race, Religion, and Reason|last1=Rawles|first1=James|url=http://survivalblog.com/lest_any_man_should_boast_a_ch/|website=survivalblog.com|publisher=James Rawles|accessdate=June 2010}}</ref>
Rawles believes that survivalists see a high risk of a coming societal meltdown and the need to prepare for the repercussions. He has said that the popular media has developed an incorrect far-right "lunatic fringe" image in part because of the actions of a radical few. He called this a distortion of the true message of survivalism. Unlike the handful of fringe proponents, Rawles focuses instead on family preparedness and personal freedom. He explains that the typical survivalist does not actually live in a rural area, but is rather a city dweller worried about the collapse of society who views the rural lifestyle as idyllic. He cautions that rural self-sufficiency actually involves "a lot of hard work".<ref name="urlSurvivalists get ready for meltdown">{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/europe/04/20/survival.feat/index.html#cnnSTCText|title=Survivalists get ready for meltdown - CNN.com|date=2 May 2008|quote=Of course, none of this kind of talk is that new. The nature of the threat may have changed but groups of various descriptions have been predicting a breakdown of society since biblical times – and very occasionally they've been right.|accessdate=22 February 2010}}</ref> In 2009, he said: "There's so many people who are concerned about the economy that there's a huge interest in preparedness, and it pretty much crosses all lines, social, economic, political and religious. There's a steep learning curve going on right now."<ref name="SP5-26-09" /> In a December 2014 interview with ''[[The Economist]]'' magazine, Rawles described the survivalist movement as decentralized and full of people who value their privacy. He said: "You don't want to be known as the guy who has 3-4 years' supply of food in the basement. Because one day you could see it confiscated by the government or stolen by neighbours like hungry locusts."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.economist.com/node/21636611/print|title=I will survive|date=2014-12-20|publisher=The Economist|accessdate=2015-11-05}}</ref>
===Blog and consulting=== Rawles is the Senior Editor of SurvivalBlog.com, a [[blog]] on survival and preparedness topics.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://charts.technorati.com/blogs/www.survivalblog.com?reactionsdaily |title=Survivalblog.com site details – Technorati |publisher=Charts.technorati.com |date= |accessdate=4 September 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131224114943/http://charts.technorati.com/blogs/www.survivalblog.com?reactionsdaily |archivedate=24 December 2013 |df= }}</ref> It has been described as "the guiding light of the prepper movement"<ref name="Forsyth">{{cite web|last=Forsyth |first=Jim |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/01/21/us-usa-civilization-collapse-idUSTRE80K0LA20120121 |title=Subculture of Americans prepares for civilization's collapse |publisher=Reuters |date=21 January 2012 |accessdate=10 February 2012}}</ref> and "the grandaddy of survival blogs".<ref>{{cite web|author=Jennifer Graham |url=http://national.deseretnews.com/article/2665/apocalypse-wow-how-end-times-fascination-fuels-the-entertainment-industry.html |title=Apocalypse Wow: How end times fascination fuels the entertainment industry | Deseret News National |publisher=National.deseretnews.com |date=2014-10-31 |accessdate=2015-11-05}}</ref> He concentrates on encouraging family preparedness for many possible threats toward society.<ref name = "NYT3-5-09">{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/05/opinion/05thu3.html?_r=1&scp=1&sq=Rawles&st=cse | work=The New York Times | title=Out of Work? Read a Recession Blog. Or, Better Yet, Write One | first=Adam | last=Cohen | date=5 March 2009 | accessdate=5 May 2010}}</ref> He has turned over day-to-day editing of the blog to others.{{citation needed|date=November 2018}} In his various writings, Rawles has warned about socio-economic collapse,<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/europe/04/20/survival.feat/index.html |title=Survivalists get ready for meltdown - CNN.com |publisher=Edition.cnn.com |date=2 May 2008 |accessdate=4 September 2013}}</ref><ref name = "Time5-17-10">{{cite news| work=Time Magazine | title=Gold Fated | first=Von Drehle | last=David | date=17 May 2010}}</ref> pandemics,<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://noisyroom.net/blog/2014/10/15/consider-this-your-last-wake-up-call-james-wesley-rawles/ |title=Consider This Your LAST Wake-Up Call – James Wesley Rawles |publisher=NoisyRoom.net |date=2014-10-15 |accessdate=2015-11-05}}</ref> X-class [[solar flares]] taking down power grids,<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/mark-rubinstein/liberators-a-talk-with-ja_b_6007686.html |title='Liberators' - a Talk With James Wesley, Rawles | Mark Rubinstein |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date=2014-10-20 |accessdate=2015-11-05}}</ref> terrorist attacks,<ref>"High Technology Terrorism." ''Defense Electronics'' magazine, January 1990, p.74.</ref> and food shortages.
==Books== Rawles has seven books in print that are sold by mainstream booksellers: five novels and two nonfiction survival books. His second nonfiction book, titled ''Tools for Survival'', was published in late 2014.<ref name="survivalblog.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.survivalblog.com/writings.html |title=SurvivalBlog.com |publisher=SurvivalBlog.com |date= |accessdate=4 September 2013}}</ref>
His novels tend to be heavy on acronyms and technical jargon,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://adviceandbeans.com/2011/10/survivors-a-great-concept-an-average-novel/ |title=Survivors: A Great Concept, An Average Novel |publisher=Advice and Beans |date=2014-03-05 |accessdate=2015-11-05}}</ref> while his non-fiction books concentrate on practical skills and tools. In the Acknowledgments note to his book ''Tools For Survival'', Rawles credits [[David Brin]], [[Algis Budrys]], [[Tom Clancy]], [[Bruce D. Clayton]], [[Colonel Jeff Cooper]], [[Frederick Forsyth]], [[Pat Frank]], [[Gordon R. Dickson|Gordon Dickson]], [[Friedrich Hayek]], [[Henry Hazlitt]], [[Ernest Hemingway]], [[Dean Ing]], [[Elmer Keith]], Herbert W. McBride, [[Ludwig von Mises]], [[Dr. Gary North]], [[Arthur W. Pink]], [[John Piper (theologian)|John Piper]], [[Jerry Pournelle]], [[Ayn Rand]], [[Lew Rockwell]], [[Murray Rothbard]], [[George R. Stewart]] and [[Mel Tappan]] as influential to his writing.<ref>''Tools For Survival'' p. xviii</ref> In his blog, Rawles also cites [[Robert A. Heinlein]] as an influence, and often quotes him.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://survivalblog.com/notes_from_jwr_698/ |title=Notes from JWR |publisher=SurvivalBlog.com |date=2013-07-07 |accessdate=2015-11-05}}</ref>
[[File:Patriots front cover.jpg|right|150px|thumb|Cover of ''Patriots'']]
===''Patriots: A Novel of Survival in the Coming Collapse''=== {{main|Patriots Novels Series}}
His first novel was a work of [[speculative fiction]] set in a near future including [[hyperinflation]] and socioeconomic collapse. Initially titled: ''Patriots: Surviving the Coming Collapse'', and later re-titled: ''[[Patriots: A Novel of Survival in the Coming Collapse]]''. The book was originally released in draft form as [[shareware]]<ref>"On-line Underground," ''The Spokesman-Review'' (Spokane). 3 December 1995, page H7</ref> under the title "Triple Ought" in the early 1990s. It was released in a printed edition by Huntington House. After Huntington House went out of business, the book was re-released by [[Xlibris]], a "print on demand" publisher. Starting in April 2009, the novel was published in a paperback edition by Ulysses Press. It was updated to include a glossary<ref>''Patriots: A Novel of Survival in the Coming Collapse'', Ulysses Press, Berkeley, California, 2009, pp. 388–393</ref>{{Self-published inline|certain=yes|date=December 2017}} and index.<ref>''Patriots: A Novel of Survival in the Coming Collapse'', Ulysses Press, Berkeley, California, 2009, pp. 394–399</ref>
In early April 2009, shortly after its release, it was ranked number 6 in Amazon.com's overall book sales rankings, but fell to number 33 a week later.<ref name="Library Journal">{{cite web |url=http://www.libraryjournal.com/article/CA6651539.html |title=Survivalist Novel Patriots Rates High in Amazon, Not Libraries |publisher=Library Journal |date=14 April 2009 |accessdate=21 February 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090425071958/http://www.libraryjournal.com/article/CA6651539.html |archivedate=25 April 2009 |df= }}</ref> By the end of the month it had fallen to number 98.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/gp/bestsellers/2009-04-27/books/ref=pd_ts_pg_4/190-5513629-2305443?ie=UTF8&pg=4 |title=Best Sellers of April 27, 2009 in Books |publisher=Amazon.com |date=27 April 2009 |accessdate=4 September 2013}}</ref> The book's initial popularity caught librarians unprepared because it was considered a niche title and had not been reviewed by the major book review publications. According to ''[[Library Journal]]'', the topic struck a chord with "a small but vociferous group of people concerned with survivalism" who share a sense of societal anxiety associated with the economic recession. The journal went on to say that ''Patriots'' was "reportedly originally conceived as a nonfiction guide. According to a number of Amazon.com reviewers, the novel will not win any literary prizes; its strength lies in its practical reassurances, focus on guns, and Christian ideology." Librarians then scrambled to purchase copies of the book to meet the unanticipated demand.<ref name="Library Journal"/>
===''Survivors: A Novel of the Coming Collapse''=== ''Survivors: A Novel of the Coming Collapse'' is a contemporaneous sequel novel that parallels the events that occur in ''Patriots'', following a hyperinflationary socioeconomic collapse and the subsequent events known as "The Crunch". The novel follows several new characters (and some characters from ''Patriots'') as they attempt to survive in the United States following The Crunch as they deal with criminal gangs, a provisional American government, and the general breakdown of society. The book was released on 4 October 2011. It rose to #2 in Amazon's overall book sales ranks, the same day. On 23 October 2011, it was listed at #3 in the ''New York Times'' Best Sellers list in the fiction hardback category.<ref name="schuessler1"/> Less than a month after publication, the novel had gone through four printings and had 52,500 copies in print.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.survivalblog.com/2011/11/note_from_jwr_1413.html |title=Note from JWR |publisher=SurvivalBlog.com |date= |accessdate=10 February 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120105173315/http://www.survivalblog.com/2011/11/note_from_jwr_1413.html |archivedate= 5 January 2012 |df= }}</ref> A Spanish edition (titled ''Superviventes''), was released in 2014.
===''Founders: A Novel of the Coming Collapse''=== ''Founders: A Novel of the Coming Collapse'' is a contemporaneous sequel that parallels the events that occur in ''Patriots'' and ''Survivors''. It was released on 25 September 2012. The book peaked at #4 in Amazon's overall book sales ranks, on its release day. The book premiered on the ''New York Times'' Best Sellers list at #11, but dropped to #27 a week later.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/10/21/books/review/inside-the-list.html|author=Gregory Cowles|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|title=Inside the List|accessdate=4 September 2013}}</ref>
===''Expatriates: A Novel of the Coming Global Collapse''=== ''Expatriates: A Novel of the Coming Global Collapse'' is a contemporaneous sequel novel that parallels the events that occur in ''Patriots'', ''Survivors'', and ''Founders'' including perspectives from [[Melanesia]] and [[Australasia]] as well as the USA. This 301-page novel was released on 1 October 2013.<ref name="survivalblog.com"/> The book debuted at #21 in hardback fiction category on the ''New York Times'' Bestsellers List.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20140223141254/http://www.survivalblog.com/2013/10/notes-from-jwr-752.html Notes from JWR:]. survivalblog.com. October 2013</ref>
===''Liberators: A Novel of the Coming Global Collapse''=== ''Liberators: A Novel of the Coming Global Collapse'' is a contemporaneous sequel novel that parallels the events that occur in ''Patriots'', ''Survivors'', ''Founders'', and ''Expatriates''. It is the final novel in the series. This 416-page novel (the longest in the series) was released in October 2014.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://survivalblog.com/notes-for-tuesday-october-21-2014/ |title=Notes for Tuesday – October 21, 2014 |publisher=SurvivalBlog.com |date=2014-10-21 |accessdate=2015-11-05}}</ref>
===''How to Survive the End of the World as We Know It: Tactics, Techniques, and Technologies for Uncertain Times''=== [[File:RawlesTEOTW.jpg|right150px|thumb|Cover of ''How To Survive The End Of The World As We Know It'']] His ''How to Survive the End of the World as We Know It: Tactics, Techniques, and Technologies for Uncertain Times'' is a non-fiction book drawn primarily from his posts on SurvivalBlog.com. The book was described as "The preppers' Bible", by a [[Reuters]] journalist.<ref name="Forsyth"/> His blog addresses preparing for the multitude of possible threats toward society. Rawles describes how to prepare against a post-disaster society that suffers looting, armed violence and [[Famine|food shortages]]. He recommends establishing rural safe havens at least 300 miles from the nearest major city, financial planning for a future [[barter]]-based economy, water retrieval and purification, food production and storage, security and self-defense techniques and strategies.<ref name="wfs" /><ref name="urltheTrumpet.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.thetrumpet.com/index.php?q=6767.5292.120.0 |title=Are You Ready for the End of the World? theTrumpet.com by the Philadelphia Church of God |accessdate=1 March 2010}}</ref>
The book received a mixed review from the ''New York Journal of Books:''
<blockquote>For a neutral assessment of the huge efforts put in by the author, the book has its own strengths and weaknesses; however, the former outweigh the latter by a huge margin. One of its crystal clear strengths is the author's obsession with precision and a clinical eye for relevant details.<ref>{{cite web|last=Wesley |first=James |url=http://www.nyjournalofbooks.com/review/how-survive-end-world-we-know-it-tactics-techniques-and-technologies-uncertain-times |title=How to Survive the End of the World As We Know It: Tactics, Techniques and Technologies for Uncertain Times | New York Journal of Books |work=New York Journal of Books |date=30 September 2009 |accessdate=4 September 2013}}</ref></blockquote>
It received a favorable book review on the weblog of Orville R. Weyrich Jr.<ref name="Weyrich">[http://www.weyrich.com/book_reviews/teotwawki.html Orville R. Weyrich, Jr. weblog book review ''The End of the World as We Know It'']. Weyrich.com. Retrieved on 30 April 2014.</ref> A summary of the book was published in the March–April 2010 issue of ''[[World Future Society|The Futurist]]'' magazine, under the headline: "Alarmingly Practical Advice For Doomsday."<ref name="wfs">[http://www.wfs.org/J-F2010/booksinbrief.htm ''The Futurist'' March–April 2010 Books in Brief, pp. 60–61]. Wfs.org. Retrieved on 30 April 2014.</ref>
Syndicated radio talk show host [[G. Gordon Liddy]] interviewed Rawles and said that his book "posits a collapse of civilization."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://feeds.radioamerica.org/loudwater/ggl/000000193_000_000000006.mp3 |title=The G. Gordon Liddy Show archived audio stream |publisher=Feeds.radioamerica.org |accessdate=4 September 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131111031017/http://feeds.radioamerica.org/loudwater/ggl/000000193_000_000000006.mp3 |archivedate=11 November 2013 |df= }}</ref> When Rawles was interviewed by radio host [[Laura Ingraham]], she described the book as going "through point-by-point the basics of being prepared and heightening your chances of surviving some type of major crisis." Ingraham said that "there is a thin line between order and total anarchy in time of a crisis, when peoples' lives are on the line—and all the niceties and the rules go out the door."<ref>{{cite web|author=Payam Zarrabizadeh |url=http://www.lauraingraham.com/pg/jsp/charts/audioMaster.jsp?size=90&dispid=304 |title=Interviews and Clips |publisher=Laura Ingraham |date= |accessdate=4 September 2013}}</ref>
''How to Survive the End of the World as We Know It'' has 14 chapters and three appendices, 336 pages, {{ISBN|978-0-452-29583-4}}. September 2009. First Printing (September 2009): 20,000 copies. Second Printing (October 2009): 6,000 copies. Third Printing (October 2009): 25,000 copies. An unabridged [[audiobook]] edition is also available ({{ISBN|978-1441830593}}), produced by Brilliance Audiobooks. It was narrated by [[Dick Hill (narrator)|Dick Hill]]. As of March 2011, there were 132,000 copies of the book in print, and it had gone through 11 printings.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.survivalblog.com/2011/03/odds_n_sods_1815.html |title=Odds 'n Sods |publisher=SurvivalBlog.com |date=17 March 2011 |accessdate=10 February 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120321114708/http://www.survivalblog.com/2011/03/odds_n_sods_1815.html |archivedate=21 March 2012 |df= }}</ref> As of April 2012, there were 12 foreign publishing contracts in place to produce editions in 11 languages,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.parismatch.com/Actu-Match/Monde/Actu/Les-survivalistes-attendent-la-fin-du-monde-453663/ |title=Les survivalistes attendent la fin du monde |language=fr |publisher=Paris Match |date= |accessdate=4 September 2013}}</ref> and the book was still in Amazon.com's Top 250 titles, overall.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://survivalblog.com/2012/04/notes-from-jwr-463.html |title=Notes from JWR |publisher=SurvivalBlog.com |date=9 April 2012 |accessdate=4 September 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131111025433/http://survivalblog.com/2012/04/notes-from-jwr-463.html |archivedate=11 November 2013 |df= }}</ref> The German edition, ''Überleben in der Krise'' was translated by Angelika Unterreiner and published in 2011 by [[Kopp Verlag]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kopp-verlag.de/%DCberleben-in-der-Krise.htm?websale8=kopp-verlag&pi=922800 |title=Überleben in der Krise – Überleben Selbstversorgung & Überleben|publisher=[[Kopp Verlag]] |date= |accessdate=4 September 2013}}→</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.seiten-ladefehler.de/uberleben-in-der-krise |title=Überleben in der Krise |publisher=Seiten-ladefehler.de |date=24 June 2011 |accessdate=4 September 2013}}</ref> The French edition, ''Fin du Monde: Comment survivre?'' was translated by Antony Angrand. It was released in September 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.librairiedialogues.fr/livre/2305681-fin-du-monde-comment-survivre--wesley-rawles-james-altipresse |title=Livre: Fin Du Monde, Comment Survivre ?, Wesley Rawles James, Altipresse, 9791090465138 – Librairie Dialogues |publisher=Librairiedialogues.fr |date=6 September 2012 |accessdate=4 September 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.de/Fin-Monde-James-Wesley-Rawles/dp/B007T5K41O/ref=sr_1_13?ie=UTF8&qid=1353698076&sr=8-13 |title=Fin de Monde : Comment survivre ?: Amazon.de: James Wesley Rawles, Antony Angrand: Bücher |publisher=Amazon.de |date= |accessdate=4 September 2013}}</ref> The Spanish edition: ''Cómo Sobrevivir al Fin del Mundo tal Como lo Conocemos'' was translated by Juan Carlos Ruiz Franco in Spain and Javier Medrano in the United States. It was released in April 2012.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://survivalblog.com/el_fin_del_mundo_-_and_then_came_the_spanish_edition/ |title=El Fin del Mundo – And Then Came The Spanish Edition |publisher=SurvivalBlog.com |date=2012-02-06 |accessdate=2015-11-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.paidotribo.com/ficha.aspx?cod=01116 |title=CÓMO SOBREVIVIR AL FIN DEL MUNDO TAL COMO LO CONOCEMOS. Tácticas, técnicas y recursos |publisher=Paidotribo |date= |accessdate=4 September 2013}}</ref> A Romanian translation (''Ghid De Supravietuir'') from Editura Paralela 45 in Bucharest was released in November 2013. It was translated by Ioan Es. Pop, a well-known Romanian poet, political figure, translator, and academic.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20140214192701/http://www.survivalblog.com/2013/11/notes-from-jwr-774.html Notes from JWR:]. survivalblog.com. November 2013</ref><ref>[[:ro:Ioan Es. Pop]]</ref>
===''Tools For Survival''=== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:ToolsforSurvival392.jpg|thumb|Cover of ''Tools For Survival'']] --> His ''Tools For Survival: What You Need to Survive When You're on Your Own'' (2014) is another non-fiction book drawn primarily from his SurvivalBlog.com posts. The publisher describes the book as "a guide to the selection, use, and care of tools." It was released on December 30, 2014, by Penguin Books, and immediately jumped to #1 in Amazon's Survival & Emergency Preparedness books category. The paperback book's ISBN is 978-0-452-29812-5. It is also sold as an e-book and audiobook.<ref>[http://www.survivalblog.com/writings.html The Writings of James Wesley Rawles]. SurvivalBlog.com (25 March 2009). Retrieved on 30 April 2014.</ref><ref>[https://www.amazon.com/Tools-Survival-What-Survive-You%C2%92re/dp/0452298121/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1397498692&sr=8-2&keywords=Rawles+Tools+for+survival Tools for Survival: What You Need to Survive When You’re on Your Own: James Wesley Rawles: 9780452298125: Amazon.com: Books]. Amazon.com (10 April 2014). Retrieved on 30 April 2014.</ref>
===''Land of Promise''=== On December 1, 2015, Rawles released the novel ''Land of Promise'', the first book in the ''Counter-Caliphate Chronicles'' novel series. This [[science fiction]] novel is a geopolitical thriller that is a considerable departure from his previous ''Patriots'' [[thriller novel]] series. Set in the late 2130s, ''Land of Promise'' fictionally describes the world under the economic and military domination of a Global Islamic Caliphate, brought about by a fictional new branch of Islam, called The Thirdists. The novel also describes the establishment of a Christian nation of refuge called The Ilemi Republic, in East Africa. This is the first book in a planned six-novel series. It is the first release from Liberty Paradigm Publishing, a publishing venture launched by Rawles in partnership with his literary agent Robert Gottlieb of Trident Media Group.<ref>http://survivalblog.com/notes-for-tuesday-december-01-2015/</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fantasticfiction.co.uk/r/james-wesley-rawles/land-of-promise.htm|title=Land of Promise|work=fantasticfiction.co.uk}}</ref>
==Philosophical, political and economic views== Rawles is an proponent of family preparedness, especially regarding food storage<ref>{{cite web|author=Josh Gerstein |url=http://www.nysun.com/news/food-rationing-confronts-breadbasket-world |title=Food Rationing Confronts Breadbasket of the World |publisher=Nysun.com |date=21 April 2008 |accessdate=21 February 2010}}</ref> and advocates relocating to lightly populated rural "[[retreat (survivalism)|retreat]]" areas. His preparedness philosophy emphasizes the fragility of modern society, the value of silver and other tangibles for barter, recognition of moral absolutes, being well-armed, maintaining a "deep larder," relocation to rural retreats, and [[Charity (virtue)|Christian charity]].<ref>How to Survive The End of the World as We Know It, Plume (Division of Penguin Books), New York, 2009, p. 11-17.</ref> In an interview in ''[[The New York Times]]'', Rawles identified himself as a "guns and groceries" survivalist.<ref name="urlEditorial Observer - Out of Work? Read a Recession Blog. Or, Better Yet, Write One. - NYTimes.com">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/05/opinion/05thu3.html |title=Editorial Observer - Out of Work? Read a Recession Blog. Or, Better Yet, Write One. - NYTimes.com |accessdate=22 February 2010 | work=The New York Times | first=Adam | last=Cohen | date=5 March 2009}}</ref>
Rawles interprets the 2nd Amendment as supporting citizens' individual rights to bear and keep arms. He believes they should be able to take arms to public events.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.foxbusiness.com/search-results/m/25952317/right-to-protest-with-a-gun.htm |title=Right to Protest ... With a Gun? |publisher=FOXBusiness.com |date= |accessdate=21 February 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090822130558/http://www.foxbusiness.com/search-results/m/25952317/right-to-protest-with-a-gun.htm |archivedate=22 August 2009 |df= }}</ref>
Rawles is opposed to racism.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ashevilledailyplanet.com/news/2828-collapse-coming-survival-guru-tailor-tips-to-carolinians |title=Collapse coming? Survival guru tailor tips to Carolinians |publisher=Ashevilledailyplanet.com |date=2012-08-09 |accessdate=2015-11-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thetrumpet.com/?q=6700.5220.0.0 |title=What Survivalists Have Right – Columns – theTrumpet.com by the Philadelphia Church of God |publisher=Thetrumpet.com |date=4 November 2009 |accessdate=10 February 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.survivalblog.com/2010/03/lest_any_man_should_boast_a_ch.html |title=Lest Any Man Should Boast: A Christian Survivalist Perspective on Race, Religion, and Reason |publisher=SurvivalBlog.com |date=10 March 2010 |accessdate=10 February 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111229185843/http://www.survivalblog.com/2010/03/lest_any_man_should_boast_a_ch.html |archivedate=29 December 2011 |df= }}</ref> He supports abolition of modern slavery in the world.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.survivalblog.com/2013/05/modern-slavery-must-end.html |title=Modern Slavery Must End! |publisher=SurvivalBlog.com |date=6 May 2013 |accessdate=4 September 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130817101927/http://www.survivalblog.com/2013/05/modern-slavery-must-end.html |archivedate=17 August 2013 |df= }}</ref>
==American Redoubt movement== {{main|American Redoubt}} In March 2011, Rawles formulated the [[American Redoubt]] movement. Rawles proposes five western states ([[Idaho]], [[Montana]], [[Wyoming]], eastern [[Oregon]], and eastern [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]]) as a safe haven for conservative Christians and Jews.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.survivalblog.com/redoubt.html |title=SurvivalBlog.com |publisher=SurvivalBlog.com |date=15 April 2011 |accessdate=10 February 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120217212813/http://www.survivalblog.com/redoubt.html |archivedate=17 February 2012 |df= }}</ref> The concept was endorsed by former Presidential candidate [[Chuck Baldwin]], who had recently relocated his entire extended family to western Montana.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newswithviews.com/baldwin/baldwin642.htm |title=Chuck Baldwin – The American Redoubt |publisher=Newswithviews.com |date=31 March 2011 |accessdate=10 February 2012}}</ref> One of its adherents, John Jacob Schmidt, started a weekly podcast called ''Radio Free Redoubt'' to help further the movement.<ref>{{cite web|author=J.J.S. |url=http://radiofreeredoubt.blogspot.com/ |title=Radio Free Redoubt |publisher=Radiofreeredoubt.blogspot.com |date=5 February 2012 |accessdate=10 February 2012}}</ref>
==Citizen Journalism facilitator== Rawles is a proponent of [[Citizen Journalism]]. In April 2014, along with his son Robert, Rawles co-founded The Constitution First Amendment Press Association (CFAPA),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cfapa.org/ |title=Constitution First Amendment Press Association (CFAPA) Free Press Credentials (Free Press Pass) - An Independent Press Association |publisher=CFAPA |date= |accessdate=2015-11-05}}</ref> a private free press advocacy group that distributes press credentials to any literate adult U.S. Citizen, free of charge.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.shtfplan.com/headline-news/the-last-line-of-defense-new-organization-aims-to-protect-citizen-journalists-we-will-stand-with-you_05142014 |title=The Last Line of Defense: New Organization Aims to Protect Citizen Journalists: "We Will Stand With You" |publisher=Shtfplan.com |date=2014-05-14 |accessdate=2015-11-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Sheets |first=David |url=http://blogs.spjnetwork.org/tech/2014/05/23/survivalist-starts-issuing-his-own-press-passes/ |title=Net Worked » Blog Archive » Survivalist starts issuing his own press passes | A Society of Professional Journalists Blog |publisher=Blogs.spjnetwork.org |date=2014-05-23 |accessdate=2015-11-05}}</ref>
==Secret ranch location== Rawles has lived in [[San Jose, California]]; near [[Orofino, Idaho]]; near [[Smartville, California|Smartsville]] in [[Fremont, California]]; and near [[New Washoe City, Nevada]]. An article published by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation in 2008 incorrectly asserted that Rawles lived in California, but later in that article, Rawles noted that the location of his ranch in the United States is kept secret, but that he lives somewhere west of the Rockies.<ref>{{cite web|author=Peter Ryan |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2008/04/28/2228908.htm |title=Global food crisis sparks US survivalist resurgence – ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation) |publisher=Abc.net.au |date=28 April 2008 |accessdate=10 February 2012}}</ref> The German newspaper ''[[Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung]]'' asserts that the ranch is in northern Idaho.<ref>{{cite news |first=Jordan |last=Mejias |date=9 May 2009 |title=Amerikanischer Bestseller: 'Patriots': Wie das Ende unserer Welt zu überleben ist – Autoren |url=http://www.faz.net/aktuell/feuilleton/buecher/rezensionen/amerikanischer-bestseller-patriots-wie-das-ende-unserer-welt-zu-ueberleben-ist-1797611.html |work=[[Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung]] |accessdate=16 April 2017}}</ref> Others have claimed that the "undisclosed location" of the ranch is in Nevada, Utah, Wyoming or even in Central America.<ref name="Sara Nelson"/><ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite web|url=http://www.survivalblog.com/contact.html |title=SurvivalBlog.com |publisher=SurvivalBlog.com |date= |accessdate=4 September 2013}}</ref> A CNN Europe article written before his first wife died noted that Rawles "... lives on a ranch in an undisclosed location with his wife (who he refers to in his blog affectionately as 'the Memsahib') and their children. Their life is almost entirely self-sufficient: They keep livestock, hunt elk and the children are schooled at home. Stored away in the ranch somewhere is a three-year supply of food."<ref>{{cite news| url=http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/europe/04/20/survival.feat/ | title=Survivalists get ready for meltdown |publisher=[[CNN]] | date=2 May 2008|accessdate=4 September 2013}}</ref> In an article titled "The Most Dangerous Novel in America", Rawles told ''The Daily Beast'': "I'm not at liberty to discuss where I live. It's part of an agreement I made with my wife. I really can't go into the details. We live in a very remote area. I embrace technology. We don't live in a cellphone area, but I'm online constantly. We're just prepared to live off-grid, if the power grid goes down. Because of the nature of my blog and my novel, I don't just want anonymity, I ''need'' anonymity. I could wake up some morning in the aftermath of some crisis and look out in my barnyard and see five Winnebagos and some television news crews. I don't want fans of my books to descend on my property, so I have to be perspicacious."<ref name="thedailybeast.com"/> In 2009, Rawles told an [[Agence France-Presse]] reporter: "I'm surrounded by national forest. A river runs through the back end of the property, so there's no shortage of water and no shortage of fish or game to shoot. If Western civilization were to collapse tomorrow, I'd have to read about it on the Internet. I just wouldn't notice."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zimbio.com/AFP+News/articles/13930/Thought+things+bad+survivalists+await+worse |title=Thought things were bad? US survivalists await worse |agency=[[Agence France-Presse]] |publisher=Zimbio |date=30 January 2009 |accessdate=10 February 2012}}</ref> His U.S. mail address is a post office box in Newcastle, Wyoming, but his main web site server is in Sweden.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>

|fam1 = [[Portuguese Creole]] |fam2 = [[Indo-Portuguese Creoles|Indo-Portuguese]] |fam3 = [[Indo-Portuguese Creoles|Northern Indo-Portuguese]] |iso3=vkp |glotto=korl1238 |glottorefname=Korlai Indo-Portuguese |lingua=51-AAC-agc }}
'''Korlai Indo-Portuguese''' is a [[creole language]] based on [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]], spoken by some 1,000 [[Luso-Indian]] [[Christian]]s in an isolated area around the village of [[Korlai]] in [[Raigad District]] of [[Maharashtra]] state, [[India]]. It is located between Goa and Daman. It has vigorous use and it is also known as '''Kristi''' ("Christian"), Korlai Creole Portuguese, Korlai Portuguese, or ''Nou Ling'' ("our language" in the language itself).
== Distribution and number of speakers == [[File:Korlai.jpg|thumb|The village of Korlai viewed from [[Korlai Fort]]]]
The village of Korlai lies on the mouth of Kundalika River, across from the ruins of [[Korlai Fort|a large Portuguese fort]], which is located in [[Revdanda]]. Until the 20th century, Korlai, its Christian inhabitants, and its language were relatively isolated from the Marathi-speaking Hindus and Muslims surrounding them. Since 1986, there is a bridge across the [[Kundalika River]], because of which industry has now moved into the area.
What is known about the history and the grammar of ''No Ling'' can be found in the 1996 book ''The Genesis of a Language: Formation and Development of Korlai Portuguese'' written by J. Clancy Clements.

{{Infobox language |name=Koyra Chiini |states=[[Mali]] |region=[[Niger River]] |speakers=200,000 |date=1999 |ref=e18 |familycolor=Nilo-Saharan |fam2=[[Songhay languages|Songhay]] |fam3=[[Southern Songhay languages|Southern]] |dia1=Djenné Chiini |iso3=khq |glotto=koyr1240 |glottorefname=Koyra Chiini Songhay |notice=IPA |map =Songhay languages.svg |mapcaption =Location of [[Songhay languages]]This map is based on classification from Glottolog and data from Ethnologue.
'''Northwest Songhay:''' {{legend|#002b00|[[Korandje language|Korandje]]}} {{legend|#008000|Koyra Chiini}} {{legend|#00ff00|[[Tadaksahak]]}} {{legend|#55ff55|[[Tasawaq language|Tasawaq]]}} {{legend|#aaffaa|[[Gadal language|Tagdal]]}} '''Eastern Songhay:''' {{legend|#2b0000|[[Tondi Songway Kiini]]}} {{legend|#800000|[[Humburi Senni language|Humburi Senni]]}} {{legend|#d40000|[[Koyraboro Senni]]}} {{legend|#ff5555|[[Zarma language]]}} {{legend|#ffaaaa|[[Dendi language|Dendi]]}} }} '''Koyra Chiini''' ({{IPA-xx|kojra tʃiːni|}}, figuratively "town language"), or '''Western Songhay''', is a member of the [[Songhay languages]] spoken in [[Mali]] by about 200,000 people (in 1999) along the [[Niger River]] in [[Timbuktu]] and upriver from it in the towns of [[Diré]], [[Tonka, Tombouctou Region|Tonka]], [[Goundam]] and [[Niafunké]] as well as in the [[Sahara|Saharan]] town of [[Araouane]] to its north. In this area, Koyra Chiini is the dominant language and the ''[[lingua franca]]'', although minorities speaking [[Hassaniya Arabic]], [[Tamasheq language|Tamasheq]] and [[Fula language|Fulfulde]] are found. '''Djenné Chiini''' {{IPA-xx|dʒɛnːɛ tʃiːni|}}, the dialect spoken in [[Djenné]], is [[mutually comprehensible]], but has noticeable differences, in particular two extra vowels ({{IPA|/ɛ/}} and {{IPA|/ɔ/}}) and syntactic differences related to [[focus (linguistics)|focalisation]]. East of Timbuktu, Koyra Chiini gives way relatively abruptly to another Songhay language, [[Koyraboro Senni]]. Unlike most Songhai languages, Koyra Chiini has no phonemic [[tone (linguistics)|tones]] and has [[subject–verb–object]] word order rather than [[subject–object–verb]]. It has changed the original Songhay ''z'' to ''j''.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=Hs028DVIPPQC&oi=fnd&pg=PR13&dq=koyra+chiini+phonology&ots=ZD8N9-gxcF&sig=W5JsxeKhb5YzqN5cLDvGBBfonyU#v=onepage&q=phonology&f=false|title=A Grammar of Koyra Chiini: The Songhay of Timbuktu|last=Heath|first=Jeffrey|date=1999-01-01|publisher=Walter de Gruyter|isbn=9783110804850|language=en}} == Phonology == Koyra Chiini has 5 vowels: /a, e, i, o, u/. All vowels have lengthened counterparts. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |+Consonants ! colspan="2" | ![[Bilabial consonant|Bilabial]] ![[Labiodental consonant|Labiodental]] ![[Alveolar consonant|Alveolar]] ![[Postalveolar consonant|Postalveolar]] ![[Palatal consonant|Palatal]] ![[Velar consonant|Velar]] ![[Glottal consonant|Glottal]] |- ! rowspan="2" |[[Stop consonant|Stop]] !voiceless |(p) | |t | | |k | |- ![[Voice (phonetics)|voiced]] |b | |d | | |g | |- ! rowspan="2" |[[Affricate consonant|Affricate]] !voiceless | | | |t͡ʃ | | | |- ![[Voice (phonetics)|voiced]] | | | |d͡ʒ | | | |- ! rowspan="2" |[[Fricative consonant|Fricative]] !voiceless | |f |s |(ʃ) | |(x) |h |- ![[Voice (phonetics)|voiced]] | | |(z) |(ʒ) | | | |- ! colspan="2" |[[Nasal consonant|Nasal]] |m | |n | |ɲ |ŋ | |- ! colspan="2" |[[Approximant consonant|Approximant]] | | | | |j |w | |- ! colspan="2" |[[Flap consonant|Flap]] | | |ɾ | | | | |} ==References== {{Reflist}} * ed. '''Limitrophe states''' are territories situated on a border or frontier.<ref name="mw">{{cite web|url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/limitrophe|title=Definition of LIMITROPHE|website=www.merriam-webster.com}}</ref> In a broad sense, it means border countries—any group of neighbors of a given nation which border each other thus forming a rim around that country. The English term derives from "''pays limitrophes''", a term in [[diplomacy|diplomatic]] [[French language|French]].<ref name="limit">{{cite book |title=Dictionnaire Manuel de Diplomatie et de Droit International Public et Privé |last=Calvo |first=Carlos |year=2009 |publisher=The Lawbook Exchange, Ltd|page=246|url=https://books.google.ru/books?id=T7DXvH0k3lcC&pg=PA102&lpg=PA102&dq=territoire+de+l'Etat+limitrophe&source=bl&ots=kcDG7wTEwz&sig=1zZdxj7tJkoNWzKjCDJZgQBjubc&hl=en#v=onepage&q=limitrophe&f=false}}</ref>
In [[ancient Rome]], the term referred to provinces at the [[borders of the Roman Empire]] ({{lang-la|limitrophus}}), which were obliged to provide billeting of the ''[[limitanei]]'' [[Roman legion|legion]]s deployed on their territory, mostly in ''[[limes]]''.<ref name="latdeu">{{cite book |title=Ausführliches lateinisch-deutsches Handwörterbuch |last=Georges |first=Karl Ernst |year=1998 |publisher=Nachdruck Darmstadt|page=Band 2, Sp. 660|url=http://www.zeno.org/Georges-1913/A/limitrophus}}</ref>
In modern history, it was used to reference provinces which seceded from the [[Russian empire]] at the end of [[World War I]], during the [[Russian Civil War]] (1917–1922), thus forming a kind of belt separating the [[Union of Soviet Socialist Republics|Soviet Russia]] from the Western powers.<ref name="Smele">{{cite book|title=Civil war in Siberia: the anti-Bolshevik government of Admiral Kolchak, 1918-1920 |last=Smele |first=John | location=London| publisher=Cambridge University Press| page=305| year=1996| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VNFiD_v6fj4C&pg=PA305&dq=limitrophe+Baltic&hl=en#v=onepage&q=limitrophe%20Baltic&f=false}}</ref>
== 1918–1939 == Before the [[Treaty of Versailles]] was signed on {{date|1919-6-28}} and even after it was not clear yet, which territories of the [[Russian Empire]], either occupied by German troops or engaged in the [[Civil War in Russia]], may maintain their independence, which they started to proclaim from late 1917. Thus the very composition of the Limitrophe zone was uncertain and varied widely. Arguing that these nations were then "the cards to change hands in big political games", among them the Baltic peoples, Poles, Lithuanians, Ukrainians, Belarusians, and so on.<ref name="AF">{{cite book|title=Ivan the Terrible: a military history |last=Filiushkin |first=Alexander | publisher=Frontline Books| year=2008| pages=264| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rycMAQAAMAAJ&dq=limitrophe+Baltic&q=limitrophe#search_anchor}}</ref>
The usage of term "limitrophe states" continued after World War I. Treaties were signed through the beginning of [[World War II]]. The ''[[Small Soviet Encyclopedia]]'' (1929) defines the limitrophe states as "states formed from the outskirts of the former Tsarist Russia, mainly from the western provinces". It includes in their list [[Estonia]], [[Latvia]], and [[Lithuania]], adding "and, partially, [[Poland]] and [[Finland]]".<ref>''Волин, Б.''. '''Лимитрофы'''. Малая Советская энциклопедия. М.: 1929, — т.4, стлб.641.</ref> Nine years later the [[Explanatory Dictionary of the Russian Language (Ushakov)|Ushakov's Explanatory Dictionary]] (1938) also syntactically 'separates' Finland from the three [[Baltic States]]: ("Estonia, Lithuania, Latvia and Finland as well"). However, Poland is not mentioned in this list.<ref name="UshakovOriginal">'''Лимитроф'''. Толковый словарь русского языка. Под ред. проф. Д.Н.Ушакова. т. 2. — М.:ОГИЗ, 1938. — стлб.61.</ref>
The Directive "On the preparation of [[Wehrmacht]] for 1939-1940" signed on {{date|1939-4-11}} by [[Adolf Hitler]] said, in particular, that: {{quote|text=The status of the limitrophe states will be defined exclusively by the military interests of Germany. As the events develop there might arise necessity to occupy the limitrophe states as far as the border of the former [[Courland]] and to annex these territories to the [[German Reich|Reich]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qA8TAQAAMAAJ&q=limitrophe+Baltic&dq=limitrophe+Baltic&hl=en|title=New Times (Directive as of {{date|1939-4-11}} on the preparation of Wehrmacht for 1939-1940)|date=1 May 1989|publisher=Newspaper "Trud,"|via=Google Books}}</ref>|sign=[[Adolf Hitler]]}}

{{China divisions by}} The article lists [[China]]'s first-level [[Administrative divisions of China|administrative divisions]] by their [[gross domestic product]] per capita in main years. All figures are given in the national currency, [[renminbi]] (CNY), and in [[USD]] at nominal values according to recent exchange rates as well as according to [[purchasing power parity]] (PPP). The [[List of Renminbi exchange rates|average CNY exchange rate]] used here is from the [[National Bureau of Statistics of China]], and [[List of Renminbi exchange rates#Purchasing power parity|CNY PPP exchange rates]] are estimated according to the [[International Monetary Fund]] (IMF). For comparison purposes, this article also displays the GDPs of [[Taiwan]] (ROC) and the [[Special administrative regions of China|special administrative regions]] (SARs) of [[Hong Kong]] and [[Macau]], which maintain separate economic systems and currencies. The following is a list of [[motto]]s connected to [[Serbia]] (and [[Serbs]]) and [[Serbian nationalism]]. Serbia has no official national motto.
{{incomplete list|date=March 2016}} *"[[Only Unity Saves the Serbs]]"<ref>{{cite book|author=Ivan Čolović|title=The Politics of Symbol in Serbia: Essays in Political Anthropology|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5EoJ-zjlvdoC&pg=PA299|date=January 2002|publisher=C. Hurst & Co.|isbn=978-1-85065-556-5|page=299}}</ref> (''Само слога Србина спасава / Samo sloga Srbina spasava''), popularly interpreted as depicted in [[acronyms]] in the [[Serbian cross]] part of the [[Flag of Serbia|flag]] and [[Coat of arms of Serbia|coat of arms]] (unofficial). *"There is not cross without three fingers"* (''Нема крста без три прста'' / ''Nema krsta bez tri prsta'').* *"For the Faith, King and Fatherland" (''За веру, краља и отачаство'' / Za veru, kralja i otačastvo), motto of the [[Royal Serbian Army]], included on cavalry flags.{{sfn|MO SCG|2007|p=71}} *"For King and Fatherland, with Faith in God" (''С вером у Бога, за краља и отаџбину / S verom u Boga, za kralja i otadžbinu''), [[Serbian Campaign of World War I|World War I]] [[Royal Serbian Army]] motto,<ref name="ThomasBabac2012">{{cite book|author1=Nigel Thomas|author2=Dusan Babac|title=Armies in the Balkans 1914-18|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HGIyl-gI6bkC&pg=PA11|date=20 May 2012|publisher=Osprey Publishing|isbn=978-1-78096-735-6|page=11}}</ref> [[World War II in Yugoslavia|World War II]] [[Chetniks]] motto,<ref name="LatasDželebdžić1979">{{cite book|author1=Branko Latas|author2=Milovan Dželebdžić|title=Četnički pokret Draže Mihailovića 1941-1945|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PB08AAAAMAAJ|year=1979|publisher=Beogradski izdavačko-grafički zavod|page=40}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Ranko Pejić|title=Srbi na Ozrenu i Vozući: život i stradanja|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jxW5AAAAIAAJ|year=1998|publisher=IPA "Miroslav"|page=229}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Toward Freedom|volume=40–42|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TBsMAQAAMAAJ|year=1991|publisher=Toward Freedom|page=3|quote=an old Chetnik slogan: "Believing in God for King and Fatherland."}}</ref> and [[Yugoslav Wars]] [[List_of_Serbian_paramilitary_formations#Yugoslav_Wars|Serbian paramilitary]] motto.<ref>{{cite book|title=The South Slav Journal|volume=22–23|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uhtpAAAAMAAJ|year=2001|publisher=Dositey Obradovich Circle|page=90}}</ref>
*"For King and Fatherland" (''За краља и отачаство'' / Za kralja i otačastvo), motto of the [[Royal Serbian Army]], included on infantry flags.{{sfn|MO SCG|2007|p=72}}
*"Liberty or Death" (''Слобода или смрт / Sloboda ili smrt''), motto of the [[Chetniks]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Heroes of the resistance|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kHJAAAAAIAAJ|year=1967|publisher=Dodd, Mead|page=96}}</ref>
*"All for [[Serbdom]] and the Fatherland" (''Све за Српство и отаџбину / Sve za Srpstvo i otadžbinu''), adopted in 1911 by [[Narodna Odbrana]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Joll|first1=James|last2=Martel|first2=Gordon|title=The Origins of the First World War|edition=3rd|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OKMuAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA113|year=2013|origyear=1984|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-317-87536-9|page=113}}</ref>
*"For the Cross and Freedom" (''За крст и слободу / Za krst i slobodu'').<ref>{{cite book|author1=Nicholai Velimirovic|author2=Randall Cantuar|title=Serbia in Light and Darkness|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fEGcdVr08EsC&pg=PA36|date=1 October 2007|publisher=Cosimo, Inc.|isbn=978-1-60206-804-9|page=36}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Canadian Club of Ottawa|title=The Canadian Club Yearbook|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dQkiAQAAMAAJ|year=1917|page=55}}</ref>
*"For the Honored Cross and Golden Liberty" (''За крст часни и слободу златну / Za krst časni i slobodu zlatnu'').<ref>{{cite book|author1=Nikolaj Velimirović|author2=Lj Ranković|title=Izabrana dela u 10 knjiga: Ustanak robova. Srbija u svetlosti i mraku. O istoriji. Duhovni preporod Evrope. O Evropi. Agonija crkve. O zapadnom hrišćanstvu|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=azATAQAAMAAJ|publisher=Glas crkve|pages=54, 57}}</ref>
*"With God, for Faith and Fatherland" (''С Богом, за веру и отечество / S Bogom, za veru i otečestvo''), motto of the [[Serbian Revolution]].
*"For Liberty and Honour of the Fatherland" (''За слободу и част Отаџбине'' / ''Za slobodu i čast Otadžbine''), motto of [[Chetniks in the Interwar period|Interwar Chetniks]],<ref>{{cite book|title=Spomenica Ljubomira Davidovića|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=stUbAAAAMAAJ|year=1940|publisher=Glavni odbor Demokratske stranke|p=270}}</ref> and currently the [[Serbian Armed Forces]].

{{refimprove|date=September 2015}} This is a listing of enterprises, gangs, and syndicates that are involved in organized crime. Tongs and outlaw motorcycle gangs, as well as terrorist, militant, and paramilitary groups are mentioned if they are involved in criminal activity for funding. However, since their stated aim and genesis is often ideological rather than commercial, they are distinct from mafia-type groups.
{{TOC limit|3}}
==[[Drug cartel]]s== {{See also|Allegations of CIA drug trafficking}}
In several drug-producing or transit countries, drug traffickers have taken advantage of local corruption and lack of law enforcement to establish cartels turning in millions if not billions of dollars each year. Sometimes if government enforcement is particularly poor, the cartels become quasi-paramilitary organizations.

==Post-Soviet organized crime== {{See also|Russian oligarchs|}}
Although organized crime existed in the Soviet era, the gangs really gained in power and international reach during the [[Perestroika|transition to capitalism]]. The term [[Russian Mafia]], 'mafiya' or mob is a blanket (and somewhat inaccurate) term for the various organized crime groups that emerged in this period from the 15 former republics of the [[USSR]] and unlike their Italian counterparts does not mean members are necessarily of Russian ethnicity or uphold any ancient criminal traditions, although this is the case for some members.

====[[yakuza|Japanese Yakuza]]==== {{Main|List of Yakuza syndicates}} ''See also [[Kenji Doihara#Criminal activities|Kenji Doihara's criminal activities]] and [[Aum Shinrikyo]]''
The [[yakuza]] of Japan are similar to the Italian mafias in that they originated centuries ago and follow a rigid set of traditions, but have several aspects that make them unique, such as their [[Body suit (tattoo)|full-body tattoos]] and their fairly open place in Japanese society. Many yakuza groups are umbrella organizations, smaller gangs reporting to a larger crime syndicate.

====Triads and other Chinese criminal organizations==== {{See also|Tiandihui|Kuomintang in Burma#CIA connection and opium trade}}
The [[Triad (underground society)|Triads]] is a popular name for a number of Chinese criminal secret societies, which have existed in various forms over the centuries (see for example [[Tiandihui]]). However, not all Chinese gangs fall into line with these traditional groups, as many non-traditional criminal organizations have formed, both in China and the Chinese diaspora.

==Drug and smuggling rings== Smuggling is a behavior that has occurred ever since there were laws or a moral code that forbade access to a specific person or object. At the core of any [[smuggling organization]] is the economic relationship between [[supply and demand]]. ==Prison gangs== Prisons are a natural meeting place for criminals, and for the purposes of protection from other inmates and business prisoners join gangs. These gangs often develop a large influence outside the prison walls through their networks. Most [[prison gang]]s do more than offer simple protection for their members. Most often, prison gangs are responsible for any drug, tobacco or alcohol handling inside correctional facilities. Furthermore, many prison gangs involve themselves in prostitution, assaults, kidnappings and murders. Prison gangs often seek to intimidate the other inmates, pressuring them to relinquish their food and other resources. In addition, prison gangs often exercise a large degree of influence over [[organized crime]] in the "free world", larger than their isolation in prison might lead one to expect.

==[[Gang|Street gangs]]== Youth gangs have often served as a recruiting ground for more organized crime syndicates, where juvenile delinquents grow up to be full-fledged mobsters, as well as providing muscle and other low-key work. Increasingly, especially in the United States and other western countries, [[street gangs]] are becoming much more organized in their own right with a hierarchical structure and are fulfilling the role previously taken by traditional organized crime.

{{Multiple issues| {{BLP sources|date=September 2018}} {{COI|date=September 2018}} }} {{Infobox Officeholder |name = Malik Amin Aslam |honorific-prefix = |honorific-suffix = |image = |order = | office = Advisor to the [[Prime Minister of Pakistan|Prime Minister]] for [[Ministry of Climate Change (Pakistan)|Climate Change]] |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf]] (2011-present) |alma_mater = [[Aitchison College]]
[[University of Engineering and Technology, Lahore]]
[[McGill University]]
[[Oxford University]] |profession = Politician |religion = Shia Islam |termstart=20 August 2018|president=[[Mamnoon Hussain]] [[Arif Alvi]]|primeminister=[[Imran Khan]]|birth_date=November 27, 1966 (age 51)|birth_place=[[Karachi]], [[Sindh]], [[Pakistan]]|office1=Minister of State for Environmental|termstart1=2002|termend=|termend1=2007|president1=[[Pervez Musharraf]]|primeminister1=[[Shaukat Aziz]]|deputy=[[Zartaj Gul]]}} '''Malik Amin Aslam''' is a [[Pakistan]]i politician who serves as Advisor to [[Prime Minister of Pakistan|Prime Minister Imran Khan]] on [[Ministry of Climate Change (Pakistan)|Climate Change]], in office since August 2018. He is a self professed [[environmentalist]] with a number of publications to his credit. He has served as a Minister of State for Environment (during Musharraf's Presidency) and is currently the [[Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf|Central Vice President of Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf]] (PTI) and also serves as the Advisor (Environment) to the Chairman of PTI [[Imran Khan]]. Aslam was elected in 2002 as the [[National Assembly (Pakistan)|Member of National Assembly]] affiliated with [[Pakistan Muslim League (Q)]] from [[Constituency NA-57|NA-57 (Attock-I)]] and served as the [[Ministry of Environment (Pakistan)|state minister for environment]] till 2007. During this period Malik Amin Aslam worked as the Prime Minister’s special envoy for reform of the UN governance system. Malik Amin Aslam has also had the privilege of chairing the G77+China negotiations group and leading Pakistan’s climate change negotiations at various COP meetings. In the 2008 elections he contested as an Independent candidate and was narrowly defeated by [[Pakistan Muslim League (N)]] leader by 299 votes. After joining PTI on November 19, 2011 he again contested 2013 elections from the same constituency and was narrowly defeated again in an election result marred by accusations of rigging and votes manipulation. He polled 56,000 votes against opponents 59,000.{{cite web|url=http://www.ecp.gov.pk/electionresult/Search.aspx?constituency=NA&constituencyid=NA-57|title=NA-57 (ATTOCK-I) Result: Announced|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://beta.dawn.com/news/1011956/petition-disposed-of-ecp-refuses-re-counting-in-na-57|title=Petition disposed of: ECP refuses re-counting in NA-57|first1=Malik|last1= Asad |first2= Yaqoob|last2=Malik|date=18 May 2013|website=DAWN}} Born in [[Karachi]] on November 27, 1966, Aslam got his early education from [[Aitchison College]] followed by BSc [[Electrical Engineering]] degree from the [[University of Engineering and Technology, Lahore]], in 1990 and an MBA in Finance from [[McGill University]] in 1993 and an MSc in [[Environmental Management]] from [[Oxford University]] in 1996. He worked as a climate change expert consultant with the [[World Bank]] and [[United Nations]] focussing on development of climate change policies in various developing countries - Malawi, East Timor, Turkey and Uzbekistan. Before entering politfcs, he served as the member of National Environmental Advisory Board and the Environmental Protection Council, he continues to be a member of [[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change]] since 1997.{{cite web|url=http://www.pakistanileaders.com.pk/profile/Malik_Amin_Aslam_Khan|title=Malik Amin Aslam Khan Profile|publisher=}} On Sep 13 2011 he was elected to serve on the governing council of [[International Union for Conservation of Nature]] for a four-year term in 2012.[http://app.com.pk/en_/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=208037&Itemid=2 Malik Amin Aslam elected member governing council IUCN] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140311195643/http://app.com.pk/en_/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=208037&Itemid=2 |date=2014-03-11 }} Malik Amin Aslam after serving as the Global Vice President of IUCN (International Union for Conservation of Nature) has again got reelected as Regional Councillor for Asia (2016-2020) at the World Conservation Congress held in Hawaii (September 2016). He is concurrently also chairing the flagship "Green Growth initiative" for the province of KPK in Pakistan – which includes the mass afforestation "Billion Tree Tsunami" project. He was chosen to serve on the high level "International Advisory Council" for the Eco-Forum Global – the leading environmental think-tank advising the Government of China. In August 2018, Prime Minister [[Imran Khan]] nominated Malik as Advisor on [[Ministry of Climate Change (Pakistan)|Climate Change]].https://www.tribune.com.pk/story/1785559/1-climate-change-challenges-await-new-minister/%3famp=1[http://pakobserver.net/detailnews.asp?id=125872 Amin Aslam joins PTI- Pakistan Observer] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140311195224/http://pakobserver.net/detailnews.asp?id=125872 |date=2014-03-11 }} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Khan Cabinet}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Aslam, Malik Amin}} [[Category:Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf politicians]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Punjabi people]] [[Category:1966 births]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Oxford]] [[Category:McGill University alumni]] [[Category:Pakistani environmentalists]] [[Category:Pakistani activists]] [[Category:People from Attock District]] [[Category:Aitchison College alumni]]

{{More footnotes|date=January 2017}} {{POV-check|date=November 2017}} "'''Mutual credit'''" (sometimes called "[[multilateral barter]]" or "[[credit clearing]]") is a term mostly used in the field of [[complementary currencies]] to describe a common, usually small scale, [[endogenous money]] system.
The term implies that [[creditors]] and [[debtors]] are the same people lending to each other, but there are several nuances. Some think of mutual credit as a type of [[currency]] but this can be problematic because no currency or money is 'issued' in the sense that most people would understand it. Cash is very rarely 'issued', accounting normally taking place on a [[ledger]], therefore it could also be called 'ledger money', a money ''system'', accounting for [[Exchange (organized market)|exchange]] or [[credit clearing]] system. The accounting is explained under [[multilateral exchange]].
==Economics== The practice of multilateral exchange can be a mere convenience, but once a common unit of account is agreed, the extent to which members can draw credit limited, a mutual credit system quickly resembles a money system. However, mutual credit is not one of the recognised [[schools of economic thought]], perhaps because its [[egalitarianism|egalitarian]] implication makes it politically unacceptable.
Even so, [[Keynes]] proposed a mutual credit system called [[International Clearing Union]] instead of a [[gold standard]], but it was rejected, likely because equal relations and payable debts would have reduced American leverage over the global economy.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Massimo|first1=Amato|last2=Luca|first2=Fantacci|title=The End of Finance|date=2009|publisher=Polity|isbn=978-0-7456-5111-8}}</ref>
The ideas can, however, be found in [[mutualism (economic theory)|mutualism]], which does value equitable exchange and cooperation.{{Citation needed|date=January 2017}}
==Characteristics== ===Sufficiency=== In the mainstream economy, money is regarded as a scarce commodity, which is rented out many times simultaneously by those who have it, to those who don't.{{Citation needed|date=January 2017}} This practice leads directly to [[Hoarding (economics)|hoarding]] and thus scarcity of money, to a growing [[wealth gap]], to the [[poverty trap]], the [[boom/bust cycle]] the [[economic growth]] 'imperative' and many other seemingly eternal social evils.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Lietaer et al|first1=Bernard|title=Money & Sustainability: the missing link|date=2012|publisher=Triarchy Press|isbn=978-1-908009-75-3|url=http://www.triarchypress.net/money-and-sustainability.html}}</ref>
Mutual credit accounting emphasises the importance of balanced exchange over the importance of property owners getting something for nothing.{{Citation needed|date=January 2017}} When every credit is matched by an equal and opposite debt, which is to say when there is no money and no interest, then supply equals demand ''a priori'', and all the problems of [[economic equilibrium]] go away.
===Elasticity of the money supply=== Similarly, the very politicised question of the size of the [[money supply]] is solved because the credit is perfectly [[elasticity (economics)|elastic]]; it is available in whatever quantity the debtor is trusted to repay. Without interest on deposits, there is no reason to hoard credit – all credit is treated as a short-term loan between trusted partners, though many systems make provision for default similar to insurance.
===Decentralisation=== The implication of mutual credit is that anyone can access credit to the extent to which they are trusted to repay. This can be contrasted to commercial credit systems in which only banks can 'issue' credit. Similarly the risk of default is spread differently.
===Seignorage=== In a fiat money system the benefits of issuing money fall to the sovereign who can spend money out of nothing. In a commercial credit system the interest from lending money out of nothing falls to the bank. In a mutual credit system, there is no seignorage mechanism, and no interest.
===Inflation=== Since the money supply is elastic, the problem of [[inflation]] (too much money in too small economy) should never happen in a mutual credit, and if it does, it indicates a failure of governance. Some systems allow the 'house' account unlimited spending, and this destroys the equilibrium, resulting either in inflation, or in recession.
===Access to credit=== National economies are biased towards fossil fuels and multinational corporations because they represent the least risk and most profit to the bank.{{Citation needed|date=January 2017}} Depending on the meaning of 'mutual' a mutual credit economy might imply that the people who give value to the money decide which endeavours deserve the privilege of credit.
===Solidarity economy=== Another meaning of mutuality emerges especially in small groups because any account's failure to close on zero affects the ability of others to meet their obligations. Thus if a member is struggling, then an onus is placed on other members to help out or be lenient, because a default reduces the spending power or liquidity of the currency for everyone.{{Citation needed|date=January 2017}}
==Symmetry== In conventional money systems there are considerable ethical [[usury|concerns around lending]] and [[debtors' prison|borrowing]]. A comparison of punishments meted out to the [[European troika|troika]] for loan sharking and the punishment to the [[Greek government-debt crisis|Greek government]] for defaulting on interest repayments shows that in modern times the political and moral superiority of creditors over debtors is near absolute.
In a mutual credit system, since everyone starts the same and ends the same, it doesn't matter who is 'ahead' or 'behind' at any given moment, or even when they reciprocate, as long as they eventually do.{{Citation needed|date=January 2017}} Every transaction involves one person extending credit to another, there is a necessary [[moral equivalence]] of creditors and debtors. Similarly, just as in banking, credit is limited to the degree to which the account-holder is trusted, in mutual credit, debit is often also limited to the degree to which the account holder is trusted to spend back to zero. In mainstream economics high bank balances are rewarded (with interest), but the celebrated members of mutual credit systems are both earning and spending.{{Citation needed|date=January 2017}}
==Governance of mutual credit systems== Mutual credit governance all stems from a single question, how much each member can be trusted.{{Citation needed|date=January 2017}} With no trust, there is no credit and therefore no transactions. But too much trust may be abused by members who are less serious about closing their accounts on zero - exactly the same as a [[Credit bubble]]. Small and egalitarian systems usually grant every account the same (positive and) negative limits. Some small systems will have a 'house' account which is collectively governed and may have greater limits. Larger systems with less trust between members, greater diversity of members or whose members' livelihoods depend on reciprocation have [[credit rating]] systems of more or less elaborate design.
An addition governance question concerns privacy. What transactions are visible to whom, and what account balances are visible to whom?
==Meaning of 'mutual'== Practitioners and theoreticians in the complementary currency movement have not yet offered a definition of mutual credit, (The place to do it would be the [http://ijccr.wordpress.com|IJCCR]) and while credit is well enough understood, just what is mutual is wide open to interpretation, it could be: * as mentioned, that the creditors and debts are the same people * that the credit risk is a mutual concern to all members of the circle, and the access to [[liquidity]] also * that every member agrees to honour the same unit of account * or even that the governance of the credit is participative, if it is. * That members take some responsibility for each other's successes (or at least ability to return their balances to zero)
==Is mutual credit 'money'?== [[Money]] is much more than a record of what we have spent and earned. Though the definition of money itself is highly contentious, it is usually important that it be generally exchanged for useful things. What makes a mutual credit accounting system, into something like a money system is the contractual obligation of account holders to close all accounts at zero, which is to say, to depart the system neither owing nor owed. The [[credit theory of money]] says clearly that money does not need to be, or be backed by, commodities like gold. Mutual credit systems can perform, reasonably well, all of the three classical [[functions of money]], as store of value, medium of exchange and unit of account.{{Citation needed|date=January 2017}} And while some heterodox economists such as [[Silvio Gesell]] argue that money should not even be used as a store of value,{{Citation needed|date=January 2017}} as a medium of exchange, mutual credit is unrivalled: * it actually records how much value has been given and how much received, * it is more readily available when needed (it doesn't have to be mined and refined first), * moving 'credit' is simply a matter of adding a ledger entry, * it provides an incentive for members to help each other exchange (see below), Note that since mutual credit transactions do not involve the movement of a commodity, are by nature both traceable and reversible, in contrast to say, [[cash]] or [[Bitcoin]].
==Examples and types of systems== There are three main social institutions said to use mutual credit today, [[trade exchange]]s, [[local exchange trading systems]], and [[timebanking]] associations, each with a number of offshoots and variations, and their own understanding of what mutual credit means.{{Citation needed|date=January 2017}}
==See also== *[[Barter|Barter exchange]] *[[Multilateral exchange]] *[[Mutualism (economic theory)|Mutualism]], a theory of individualist anarchism which favors mutual credit banking *[[Rotating savings and credit association|Savings pools]] are ways for mutually trusting groups to lend money to each other *[[WIR Bank]]
