{{infobox Organization | name = Overseas Development Institute | image = Overseas Development Institute logo.png | image_size = 200px | abbreviation = ODI | motto = To inspire and inform policy and practice which lead to the reduction of poverty, the alleviation of suffering and the achievement of sustainable livelihoods in developing countries | formation = {{start date and age|df=yes|paren=yes|1960}} | type = [[Think Tank]] | headquarters = 203 [[Blackfriars Road]], London SE1 8NJ | location = London, United Kingdom | leader_title = Director | leader_name = | website = {{url|http://www.odi.org.uk}} }}
The '''Overseas Development Institute''' ('''ODI''') is an independent [[think tank]] on [[international development]] and humanitarian issues, founded in 1960. Based in London, its mission is "to inspire and inform policy and practice which lead to the reduction of poverty, the alleviation of suffering and the achievement of sustainable livelihoods in [[developing countries]]." It does this by "locking together high-quality applied research, practical policy advice, and policy-focused dissemination and debate."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.odi.org.uk/about/mission-values.asp |title=Organisational information – About us – Overseas Development Institute |publisher=ODI |date= |accessdate=6 July 2012}}</ref>
==History== In 1960 ODI began in small premises in Regent's Park, central London and operated a library devoted to international development issues as well as performing consultancy work and contracts with the [[Department for International Development]] (then known as the Overseas Development Agency) of the UK government.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.odi.org.uk/50years/default.asp#timeline |title=at 50 – About ODI – Overseas Development Institute |publisher=ODI |date=9 June 2010 |accessdate=6 July 2012}}</ref> Since then it has moved several times and is currently{{when|date=January 2015}} on Blackfriars Road.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.odi.org.uk/about/contact-details |title=Contact details and directions – About us – Overseas Development Institute |publisher=ODI |date= |accessdate=9 November 2012}}</ref>
Since 2004 it has had a Partnership Programme Arrangement with the UK's Department for International Development.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dfid.gov.uk/Documents/funding/ppa/currentppas/odi-ppa-2008-11.pdf?epslanguage=en|title= Partnership Program Arrangement (PPA) between UK Department for International Development (DFID) and Overseas Development Institute (ODI) 2008–2011|format=PDF}}</ref> The Institute also developed a strong focus on communications and 'bridging research and policy'.<ref>Maxwell, Simon, and Diane L. Stone, eds. Global knowledge networks and international development. Routledge, 2004.</ref>
In 2007 the ODI was named 'Think Tank of the Year' by ''Public Affairs News'' magazine.<ref>[http://www.publicaffairsnews.com publicaffairsnews.com]</ref> It was named 'Think-tank to Watch' in the ''[[Prospect (magazine)|Prospect]]'' 'Think-tank of the Year' awards in 2005 and is considered to be in international policy circles to be one of the world's leading think tanks on development. <ref>Stone, Diane. "Rapid knowledge:‘Bridging research and policy’at the Overseas Development Institute." Public Administration and Development 29, no. 4 (2009): 303–315.</ref> It celebrated its 50th anniversary in 2010, with guests including former ODI Fellow and UK Business Secretary, [[Vince Cable]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.odi.org.uk/50years/ |title=at 50 – About ODI – Overseas Development Institute |publisher=ODI |date=9 June 2010 |accessdate=6 July 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uHAWj3-MHPQ |title=Vince Cable MP at ODI's 50th Anniversary |publisher=YouTube |date= |accessdate=6 July 2012}}</ref>
==Organisation== {{As of| 2014}} ODI had more than 230 staff.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.odi.org/about |title= About ODI – Overseas Development Institute |publisher=ODI |date=n.d. |accessdate=24 January 2015}}</ref> The Executive Director is Alex Thier. From 2013 until 2016 it was directed by [[Kevin Watkins]] who took over from Dr [[Alison Evans]], formerly of the [[Institute of Development Studies]] (IDS) at Sussex University.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.odi.org.uk/about/staff/details.asp?id=135&name=alison-evans |title=Alison Evans – Staff – About ODI – Overseas Development Institute |publisher=ODI |date= |accessdate=6 July 2012}}</ref> ODI does not engage in teaching. {{As of| 2015}} ODI had the following programmes that focus on aspects of [[international development]]:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.odi.org.uk/work/programmes/ |title=Programmes – Work – Overseas Development Institute |publisher=ODI |date= |accessdate=6 July 2012}}</ref> * Agricultural Development and Policy * Centre for Aid and Public Expenditure (CAPE) * Climate and Energy * Communications (for dispersal of ODI events and publications) * Development Strategy and Finance * Growth, Poverty and Inequality * Humanitarian Policy Group * International Economic Development Group * Politics and Governance * Public Finance and Institutions * Research and Policy in Development * Risk and Resilience * Social Development * Social Protection and Social Policy * Water Policy
===Event series and publications=== ODI hosts regular event series with conferences and panels discussing a wide range of development issues. Speakers include ODI staff,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.odi.org.uk/events/details.asp?id=2626&title=governance-africa |title=Governance for development in Africa: building on what works – Events – Overseas Development Institute |publisher=ODI |date= |accessdate=6 July 2012}}</ref> visiting development policymakers,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.odi.org.uk/events/details.asp?id=2560&title=development-progress-future-challenges |title=After 2015: new challenges in development – learning from success – Events – Overseas Development Institute |publisher=ODI |date= |accessdate=6 July 2012}}</ref> DFID officials and other prominent figures such as [[Justin Yifu Lin]], the former [[World Bank Chief Economist]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.odi.org.uk/events/audio-video.asp?id=2048&title=role-industrial-policy-development |title=The role of industrial policy in development (Audio / video) – Events – Overseas Development Institute |publisher=ODI |date= |accessdate=6 July 2012}}</ref>
ODI has published many books, papers, briefings, and two academic journals, ''[[Development Policy Review]]'' and ''[[Disasters]]''. In November 2013 an ODI report on fossil fuel subsidies and climate was published,<ref name=ReportNov2013>{{cite web|title=Time to change the game Fossil fuel subsidies and climate|author=Shelagh Whitley November 2013|url=http://www.odi.org.uk/sites/odi.org.uk/files/odi-assets/publications-opinion-files/8668.pdf|publisher=Overseas Development Institute |date=November 2013|accessdate=24 December 2013}}</ref> followed up by another report about the same topic a year later,<ref name=odi1114>{{cite web|author1=Elizabeth Bast |author2=Shakuntala Makhijani |author3=Sam Pickard |author4=Shelagh Whitley |title=The fossil fuel bailout: G20 subsidies for oil, gas and coal exploration|url=http://www.odi.org/publications/8678-fossil-fuel-bailout-g20-subsidies-oil-gas-coal-exploration|publisher=ODI|accessdate=25 January 2015|format=pdf|date=November 2014}}</ref> which was discussed by [[BBC]],<ref name=bbc>{{cite news|author1=Roger Harrabin|title=Fossil fuel promises are being broken, report says Roger Harrabin By|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-29985382|accessdate=25 January 2015|publisher=BBC|date=11 November 2014}}</ref> [[the Guardian]]<ref>{{cite news|author1=John Vidal|title=Rich countries subsidising oil, gas and coal companies by $88bn a year|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2014/nov/11/rich-countries-subsidising-oil-gas-and-coal-companies-by-88bn-a-year|accessdate=25 January 2015|work=The Guardian|date=10 November 2014}}</ref> and [[Die Welt]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Studie: Staaten zahlen Milliarden zur Erkundung von Ölvorkommen|url=https://www.welt.de/newsticker/news2/article134214541/Studie-Staaten-zahlen-Milliarden-zur-Erkundung-von-Oelvorkommen.html|accessdate=25 January 2015|work=Die Welt|publisher=WeltN24 GmbH|date=11 November 2014}}</ref>
=== Fellowship === ODI runs a fellowship scheme, which sends young postgraduate economists of all nationalities to work in the public sectors of developing countries in Africa, the Caribbean, South Asia, South East Asia and the Pacific on two-year contracts. Since 1963 ODI has sent over 900 post-graduate economists to work in 40 mostly low-income countries. Participants were initially known as Overseas Development Institute Nuffield Fellows (ODINs) and later titled as ODI Fellows.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.odi.org.uk/fellowship-scheme/ |title=Fellowship Scheme – Overseas Development Institute |publisher=ODI |date= |accessdate=6 July 2012}}</ref>
===Funding=== As a [[registered charity]], ODI's income relies on "grants and donations from foundations, non-governmental organisations, the private sector, governments, multilateral agencies and academia".
For its £28,541,000 income (USD 42,811,000 as of January 2015) per its annual report from 2013 to 2014 ending 31 March 2014,<ref name=report>{{cite web|title=annual report 2013-14|url=http://www.odi.org/sites/odi.org.uk/files/odi-assets/publications-opinion-files/9127.pdf|publisher=Overseas Development Institute|accessdate=25 January 2015|pages=1|format=pdf|date=March 2014}}</ref> ODI provided a list of these "major donors", which include Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, Oxfam, PricewaterhouseCoopers, Research Triangle Institute, Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency, Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation, Swiss Federal Government, The Prince's Youth Business International, UN Women, UNICEF, United Nations Development Programme, United Nations Environment Programme, United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization, US Agency for International Development, Wiley-Blackwell, William and Flora Hewlett Foundation, World Bank.<ref name=donors>{{cite web|title=Major donors|url=http://www.odi.org/sites/odi.org.uk/files/odi-assets/publications-opinion-files/9133.pdf|publisher=Overseas Development Institute|accessdate=25 January 2015|pages=1|format=pdf|date=March 2014}}</ref>
==Criticism== David Steven of Global Dashboard criticised the ODI for not making the distinction between subsidy and having a lower [[VAT]] rate on fuel comparison to other goods.<ref name=GlobalDashboard>{{cite web|url=http://www.globaldashboard.org/2013/11/07/odi-calls-vat-hike-energy-bills/|title=ODI calls for VAT hike on energy bills (updated: ODI fights back)|publisher=Global Dashboard|accessdate=24 December 2013}}</ref>

'''Parpública''', officially '''Participações Públicas (SGPS) S.A.''', is a state holding company that can be characterized as a [[National_wealth_fund|National Wealth Fund]] of the [[Portuguese Republic]]. The company is based in Lisbon, Portugal. Among its major assets are [[TAP Portugal]], [[ANA - Aeroportos de Portugal]], [[Águas de Portugal]], [[Imprensa Nacional Casa da Moeda]], [[Companhia das Lezírias]] and the [[Estoril Circuit]].

[[File:A parrot- joshiyam.jpg|right|thumb|250px|Parrot astrology in action]] [[File:Hindus and their Prayers (p.65, May 1865, XXII).jpg|thumb|250px|Hindus and their Prayers (p.65, May 1865, XXII)<ref name=Offering1865>{{cite journal|title=Hindus and their Prayers|journal=Wesleyan Juvenile Offering|date=May 1865|volume=XXII|pages=65|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1VwEAAAAQAAJ&lr&source=gbs_book_other_version|accessdate=1 December 2015|publisher=Wesleyan Mission House|location=London}}</ref>]] '''Parrot astrology''' or '''Parrot fortune-telling''' ({{lang-ta|கிளி ஜோசியம்}}) is a type of [[astrology]] popular among the [[Tamil people|Tamils]] of [[Tamil Nadu]], Telugus in [[Andhra Pradesh]], India and Singapore. It involves using green parakeets which are trained to pick up [[Tarot]] like fortune cards.<ref name=dc/><ref name=sing/> The parakeets are trained specifically for this.
==Fortune telling process== A parrot astrologer/fortune teller typically sits beneath a tree to call or by the side of the road where people congregate in numbers. He has a cage which contains one or two trained parrots. The tarot like cards are either spread out or stacked in front of him. They are 27 in number representing the Indian cosmic system. Each card contains the image of a Hindu deity and some cards contain images of Buddha or Virgin Mary with Infant Jesus. When a patron sits before the fortune teller, the latter opens the cage and lets the parrot out. He instructs the parrot to pick a card for the patron. The parrot walks over to the cards, picks one from the stack or the spread with its beak and gives it to the astrologer. It then walks back inside its cage. The astrologer opens the card and based on the image tells the fortune of the patron.<ref name=dc>{{cite news|title=Art of parrot predictions on verge of extinction|url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/channels/cities/chennai/art-parrot-predictions-verge-extinction-215|accessdate=23 December 2011|newspaper=[[Deccan Chronicle]]|date=17 October 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120506033522/http://www.deccanchronicle.com/channels/cities/chennai/art-parrot-predictions-verge-extinction-215|archivedate=6 May 2012|df=}}</ref><ref name=sing>{{cite web|last=Naidu Ratnala|first=Thulaja|title=Parrot astrologers|url=http://infopedia.nl.sg/articles/SIP_602_2005-01-04.html|work=National Library Board Singapore|accessdate=23 December 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120101025350/http://infopedia.nl.sg/articles/SIP_602_2005-01-04.html|archivedate=1 January 2012|df=}}</ref>
The practice of Parrot astrology is diminishing in Tamil Nadu due to lack of patronage.<ref name=dc/> In Singapore it is a tourist attraction in [[Little India, Singapore|Little India]] along the [[Serangoon Road]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Hatton|first=Michael J|title=Community-based tourism in the Asia-Pacific|year=1999|publisher=School of Media Studies at Humber College|isbn=978-0-9682334-2-9|pages=60|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UMaAAAAAMAAJ&q=parrot+astrology&dq=parrot+astrology&hl=en&sa=X&ei=6SL0To_YGIL4rQeNgpm8CA&redir_esc=y}}</ref> A variant is practiced in Pakistan.<ref>{{cite news|title=Fortune tellers thrive on public hope|url=http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=story_11-10-2004_pg7_35|accessdate=23 December 2011|newspaper=Daily Times|date=11 October 2004}}</ref>
==Gallery== {{commons category}} <gallery> File:Parrot horoscope.jpg|A parrot astrologer sitting beneath a tree File:Astrology,parrot,rural,,nainar palayam,Tamil Nadu429.JPG| A patron seeks her fortune File:A -parrot zodiac.jpg|Parrot going through the cards File:Singapore fortune teller.jpg| [[Mani the parakeet]] </gallery>

'''Picinguabas''' were people indigenous to the [[Campo Grande|Campo Grande, Rio de Janeiro]] neighborhood of [[Rio de Janeiro]] until 1565, when the first Portuguese colonists arrived there.
It is also the name of the last beach of [[Ubatuba]] in São Paulo, which shares a border with [[Paraty]] in Rio de Janeiro, and is the research center for the [[Parque Estadual da Serra do Mar]]. Here there are numerous footpaths through the Atlantic forest, as well as beaches and rivers.

The '''Polynesian Panther Party''' was a revolutionary movement founded by New Zealand born [[Polynesia]]ns on 16 June 1971.<ref name=stuff>{{cite web |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/sunday-news/news/3806084/Polynesian-Panthers-make-movie |title=Polynesian Panthers make movie |author=Bunting, Finbarr |date=June 13, 2010 |work=stuff.co.nz |accessdate=December 30, 2010 }}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The party was explicitly influenced by the [[Black Panther Party|American Black Panther Party]], particularly [[Huey Newton]]’s policy of black unity. They located the causes of [[Māori people|Māori]] and [[Pacific Islanders|Pacific Island]] oppression within the exploitative social relations of [[capitalism]]. Consequently, the Polynesian Panthers promoted a strategy of liberation based on the complete overthrow of the capitalist system and the social relations necessary for its development. The group greatly increased in profile during [[Rob Muldoon]]'s immigration scare campaign in 1975, and the subsequent [[dawn raid]]s under his administration.
==Foundation== The Polynesian Panther Movement was founded in inner city [[Auckland]] by six young [[Pacific]] Islander men: Fred Schmidt, Nooroa Teavae, Paul Dapp, Vaughan Sanft, Eddie Williams and [[Will 'Ilolahia]].<ref name=stuff/> At the time many Pacific Island youth were supporters of [[Māori political initiatives]] such as the [[Bastion Point|Bastion Point occupation]] and [[Waitangi Day]] protests, and gained skills in political lobbying and processes which they used to raise the profile of Pacific people in New Zealand. Because of the working-class background of its members the movement concerned itself with issues relating to unequal pay and unsatisfactory working conditions.
Headquarters were established in [[Ponsonby, New Zealand|Ponsonby]] and the Polynesian Panthers began to organise activities, among them were homework centres for Pacific children, visiting Pacific prisoners as well as providing transport for their families to visit, and running programs educating Pacific Islanders on their rights as New Zealand citizens. Soon the movement expanded nationally with chapters in South Auckland, [[Christchurch]] and [[Dunedin]], as well as a chapter in [[Sydney]], Australia.
One of the notable early members of the Polynesian Panthers include [[Niue]]an composer, musician and activist [[Tigilau Ness]], who was imprisoned during anti-apartheid protests in New Zealand aimed at stopping the controversial [[1981 South Africa rugby union tour of New Zealand|1981 South African Springboks rugby tour]]. Ness is also the father of New Zealand hip hop artist [[Che Fu]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/grey-lynn/news/article.cfm?l_id=340&objectid=10391310 |title=Brown Power |author=Masters, Catherine |date=July 15, 2006 |work=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |accessdate=December 30, 2010}}</ref>
==Recent years== In 2006 Panther members released a book to mark the 35th anniversary of the Polynesian Panther movement.<ref name=stuff/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://tvnz.co.nz/content/752642/2483318.html |title=Polynesian Panthers mark 35 years |date=June 17, 2006 |work=[[Television New Zealand]] |accessdate=December 30, 2010}}</ref>
On 12 September 2009 the Polynesian Panthers held a special evening in Auckland to honour American Black Panther revolutionary artist [[Emory Douglas]] during his International Artist in Residency at [[Auckland University]]'s [[Elam School of Fine Arts]].
In 2010 a documentary film made by Nevak 'Ilolahia (niece of Will 'Ilolahia), was released telling the story of the Polynesian Panthers. It was shown on [[Māori Television]]'s New Zealand documentary slot.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://paradiseishell.wordpress.com/2010/10/03/the-polynesian-panther-party-documentary/ |title=The Polynesian Panther Party documentary |date=October 3, 2010 |work=paradiseishell.wordpress.com |publisher= |accessdate=December 30, 2010| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120316155602/http://paradiseishell.wordpress.com/2010/10/03/the-polynesian-panther-party-documentary/ | archivedate=2012-03-16 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AtEKpTJXPmQ|title=Polynesian Panthers Part 1|publisher=[[YouTube]]|accessdate=25 June 2014}}</ref> A [[Facebook]] page shares news and events related to the Polynesian Panthers and showings of the documentary.<ref>{{facebook|pages/Polynesian-Panthers-Documentary/146131108750623|Polynesian Panthers Documentary}} Retrieved 25 June 2014.</ref>
==See also== * [[Black Panther Party]] * [[Black Panthers (Israel)]] * [[Māori protest movement]]

[[Reed Publishing (NZ)]] {{ISBN|0-7900-1001-1}} *"[http://www.salient.org.nz/features/how-the-polynesian-panthers-changed-our-world How the Polynesian Panthers changed our world]" ''[[Salient (magazine)]]'', by Zoe Reid 31/05/10

All prisoners have the basic [[rights]] needed to survive and sustain a reasonable way of life. Most rights are taken away ostensibly so the prison system can maintain order, discipline, and security.{{cn|date=May 2015}} Any of the following rights, given to prisoners, can be taken away for that purpose:
Prisoner may refer to one of the following: * A person incarcerated in a [[prison]] or [[jail]] or similar facility. * [[Prisoner of war]], a [[combatant]] or [[non-combatant]] in [[war]]time, held by a [[belligerent]] power * [[Political prisoner]], someone held in prison for their [[ideology]]. * A person forcibly detained against his will, such as a victim of kidnapping; such prisoners may be held hostage, or held to ransom, but not necessarily in a prison or similar facility.{{cn|date=November 2015}}
The right to: {{cn|date=November 2015}} * not be punished cruelly or unusually * due processes * administrative appeals * access the [[parole]] process (denied to those incarcerated in the Federal System) * practice religion freely * equal protection ([[Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fourteenth Amendment]]) * be notified of all charges against them * receive a written statement explaining [[evidence]] used in reaching a [[disposition]] * file a [[civil suit]] against another person * medical treatment (both long and short term) * treatment that is both adequate and appropriate * a hearing upon being relocated to the [[mental health facility]]. * [[personal property]] such as: cigarettes, stationary, a watch, cosmetics, and snack-food * visitation * [[privacy]] * food that would sustain an average person adequately. * bathe (for sanitation and health reasons).
Many rights are taken away from prisoners often temporarily.{{cn|date=November 2015}} For example, prison personnel are required to read and inspect all in-going or out-going mail, in order to prevent prisoners from obtaining [[contraband]]. The only time a prisoner has a full right to privacy is in conversations with their [[Lawyer|attorney]].

'''Prostitution in Costa Rica''' is legal. [[Costa Rica]]'s legal system is based on [[Roman law]] rather than [[common law]], and so for [[prostitution]] to be illegal it would have to be explicitly stated as such in a penal code, and it is not. Nevertheless, many of the activities surrounding it are illegal,<ref>{{cite web|title=Código Penal, Ley No. 4573 de 1970 y reformas hasta 26 de febrero de 2002|author=Asamblea Legislativa de la República de Costa Rica|url=http://www.oas.org/Juridico/MLA/sp/cri/sp_cri-int-text-cpenal.pdf|format=PDF|language=Spanish|accessdate=2007-03-17}}see SECCIÓN III: Corrupción, proxenetismo, rufianería (Articles 167 to 172).</ref> as the law forbids promoting or facilitating the prostitution of another, and therefore [[pimping]], [[brothels]], or prostitution rings are illegal.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.laflecha.net/canales/blackhats/200412073/|title=Promoción de la prostitución: Unos 130 sitios de internet promueven el turismo sexual de Costa Rica|publisher=LaFlecha.net|date=2004-12-07|accessdate=2007-03-17|language=Spanish|quote=...prostitution is not penalized in the country, but a third-party soliciting clients for a prostitute (''proxenetismo'') is committing a crime|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070513014253/http://www.laflecha.net/canales/blackhats/200412073/|archivedate=2007-05-13|df=}}(free translation from Spanish)</ref><ref>{{cite news | first= | last= | coauthors= | title=Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Costa Rica| date= | publisher=U.S. State Department | url =https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2005/61722.htm | work = | pages = |accessdate = 2007-09-28 | language =| quote =...There are no specific laws against sex tourism, which was growing}}</ref><ref name="US state">{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2008/wha/119154.htm|title=2008 Human Rights Report: Costa Rica|date=2009-02-25|website=Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor|publisher=U.S. Department of State|accessdate=7 May 2009}}</ref> Prostitution is common and is practiced openly throughout the country, particularly in popular tourism destinations.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nacion.com/ln_ee/2004/diciembre/05/ultima-ce1.html|title=Unos 130 sitios de internet promueven turismo sexual Costa Rica|publisher=[[La Nacion (Costa Rica)|La Nación]]|date=2004-12-05|accessdate=2007-03-16|language=Spanish}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Otto Vargas|url=http://www.nacion.com/ln_ee/2004/diciembre/05/sucesos0.html|title=Agencias ofrecen en el exterior damas para vacaciones eróticas en Costa Rica|publisher=La Nación |date=2004-12-04|language=Spanish|accessdate=2007-03-16}}</ref><ref name=Ávalos/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/10/13/costa-rica-sex-trade-thri_n_318364.html|title=Costa Rica Draws Sex Trade|publisher=[[The Miami Herald]]|date=2009-10-13|accessdate=2011-10-29}}</ref>
The large growth in [[sex tourism]] prompted the Government of Costa Rica introduce a voluntary<ref name="costa3">{{cite web|title=Part 3 - CR Sex Tourism; Loving Gringos for a Living|url=https://www.costaricantimes.com/part-3-cr-sex-tourism-loving-gringos-for-a-living/14819|website=The Costa Rican Times|accessdate=12 April 2018|date=23 April 2013}}</ref> registration scheme for prostitutes.<ref name="costa">{{cite web|title=Costa Rica Prostitution|url=https://www.costaricantimes.com/costa-rica-prostitution/214|website=The Costa Rican Times|date=24 April 2012}}</ref> [[Prostitute]]s who register with the [[Costa Rican Social Security Fund|Caja Costarricense de Seguro Social]] (CCSS) carry an ID card and are entitled to a free health check every 15 days.<ref name="sanjosecostarica">{{cite web|title=Costa Rica Prostitution - What's the Deal With Prostitutes?|url=http://www.sanjosecostarica.com/costa-rica-prostitution/|website=San Jose Costa Rica|accessdate=12 April 2018}}</ref> They are also receive support and assistance<ref name="costa" /> There are estimated to be 15,000 prostitutes in the country.<ref name="haverstock">{{cite web|title=Number of Prostitutes by Country - Havocscope|url=https://www.havocscope.com/number-of-prostitutes/|website=Havocscope|accessdate=11 February 2018}}</ref> Many of them are from [[Colombia]], [[Nicaragua]], [[Argentina]], [[Venezuela]], the [[Dominican Republic]]<ref name="costa" /> and other [[Latin America]]n countries.<ref name="costa3" />
There is a [[red-light district]] in the capital, [[San José, Costa Rica|San José]], known as Gringo Gulch.<ref name="sanjosecostarica" />
[[Sex trafficking]],<ref name="state17" /> [[child prostitution]]<ref name="Child" /> and [[HIV]]<ref name="unaids16" /> are problems in the country
==Sex tourism== Sex tourism in Costa Rica has been a consequence of the rapid growth of international [[Tourism in Costa Rica|tourism in the country]], and the country is being promoted as a popular destination for sex tourism.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nacion.com/ln_ee/2004/diciembre/05/ultima-ce1.html |title=Unos 130 sitios de internet promueven turismo sexual Costa Rica |publisher=La Nación |date=5 December 2004 |accessdate=16 March 2007 |language=Spanish}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Otto |last=Vargas |url=http://www.nacion.com/ln_ee/2004/diciembre/05/sucesos0.html|title=Agencias ofrecen en el exterior damas para vacaciones eróticas en Costa Rica |publisher=La Nación |date=4 December 2004 |language=Spanish |accessdate=16 March 2007}}</ref><ref name=Ávalos>{{cite news|author=Ángela Ávalos |url=http://www.nacion.com/ln_ee/2008/junio/22/pais1567973.html |title=Cien personas escapan de redes de tráfico de almas en Jacó|trans-title=One hundred people escape from human trafficking networks in Jacó|publisher=La Nación |date=22 June 2008 |language=Spanish |accessdate=22 June 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/10/13/costa-rica-sex-trade-thri_n_318364.html|title=Costa Rica Draws Sex Trade|publisher=The Miami Herald|date=13 October 2009 |accessdate=29 October 2011}}</ref> Despite the government and industry efforts, child sex trade has been also a problem.<ref name=Wright>{{cite news | first=Phillip |last=Wright |title=Sex tourism: Lessons learned in Costa Rica |date=18 June 2004 |publisher= |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/this_world/3818871.stm |work=BBC News |accessdate=21 December 2007}}</ref><ref 400 dominicanas para prostitución |publisher=La Nación |date=7 April 2008 |first=Otto |last=Vargas |accessdate=7 April 2008 |language=Spanish}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book |last=Schifter-Sikora 4573 de 1970 y reformas hasta 26 de febrero de 2002 |author=Asamblea Legislativa de la República de Costa Rica |url=http://www.oas.org/Juridico/MLA/sp/cri/sp_cri-int-text-cpenal.pdf |format=PDF |language=Spanish |accessdate=17 March 2007}} see SECCIÓN III: Corrupción, proxenetismo, rufianería (Articles 167 to 172).</ref> such as pimping.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.laflecha.net/canales/blackhats/200412073/ |title=Promoción de la prostitución: Unos 130 sitios de internet promueven el turismo sexual de Costa Rica|publisher=LaFlecha.net |date=7 December 2004 |accessdate=17 March 2007 |language=Spanish |quote= ...prostitution is not penalized in the country, but a third-party soliciting clients for a prostitute (''proxenetismo'') is committing a crime}} (free translation from Spanish)</ref><ref>{{cite web | first= |last= |title=Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Costa Rica |date= |publisher=U.S. State Department |url=https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2005/61722.htm |website= |accessdate=28 September 2007 |quote =...There are no specific laws against sex tourism, which was growing}}</ref>
=== History of tourism === Costa Rica first began development of its tourism industry with the creation of the first private hotel, the [[Gran Hotel (Costa Rica)|Gran Hotel Costa Rica]], in 1930. Generally, tourists came from overseas, entering the country through the [[Port of Limón]], then commuting to San José by train. On June 16, 1931, Law 91 was passed, creating the National Tourism Board, which operated until it was replaced by the [[Instituto Costarricense de Turismo]] on August 9, 1955.<ref>{{cite web | title=General Framework |url=http://www.visitcostarica.com/ict/paginas/TourismBoard.asp |publisher=Instituto Costarricense de Turismo |accessdate=17 October 2012}}</ref>
Currently, tourism ranks as Costa Rica’s second highest source of revenue. In 2000, revenue from tourism accounted for 21% of Costa Rica’s total exports. Increasingly, Costa Rica is becoming reliant upon tourism as a source of income; the number of tourists arrivals in 2000 had more than doubled compared to the number of tourists only a decade earlier.<ref>{{cite web |last=Inman |first=Crist |title=Tourism in Costa Rica: The Challenge of Competitiveness |url=http://www.incae.edu/ES/clacds/publicaciones/pdf/cen653.pdf |publisher=INCAE |accessdate=17 October 2012}}</ref>
=== Prominence === Recently, [[Interpol]] named Costa Rica the fastest-growing capital for sex tourism in Latin America.<ref>{{cite web | last=Ercolani |first=Steve |title=Study Looks at Costa Rica's Sex Tourism Industry |url=http://www.ticotimes.net/Current-Edition/News-Briefs/Study-looks-at-Costa-Rica-s-sex-tourism-industry_Thursday-October-04-2012 |publisher=Tico Times |date=4 October 2012 |accessdate=17 October 2012}}</ref> [[Jacó, Costa Rica|Jacó]] and San José are two of Costa Rica’s most prominent sex tourism locations. Money made by prostitutes is enough to keep the majority of Jacó’s businesses open during the off season, as it provides a significant economic supplement.<ref name="Underground">{{cite web |last=Strange |first=Cadence |title=The Not So Underground World of Sexual Tourism in Jaco Costa Rica |url=http://news.co.cr/the-not-so-underground-world-of-sexual-tourism-in-jaco-costa-rica/9849/ |publisher=The Costa Rica Star |date=5 July 2012 |accessdate=17 October 2012}}</ref> Americans are the majority of Costa Rica’s sex tourists, composing 80% of the total number of tourists.<ref name="Attractions">{{cite web |last=Song |first=Susan |title=Children as Tourist Attractions |url=http://www.yapi.org/rpchildsextourism.pdf |website=Global Child Sex Tourism |publisher=Youth Advocate Program International |accessdate=17 October 2012}}</ref>
== Violence against prostitutes== Street violence in Costa Rica is on the rise, and prostitutes are particularly at risk. Acts of violence committed towards prostitutes often go ignored. The issue of violence towards prostitutes is not an issue that goes unnoticed by policy-makers and physicians. Rather, many choose to disregard the plight of these women. Women seeking medical treatment or asylum are generally ignored and thought to be deserving of the violence they suffer. Physicians and doctors who were interviewed openly admitted to disliking prostitutes, with one physician stating these women are "an embarrassment to the country".<ref name=Hurts>{{cite journal |last=Downe |first=Pamela J. |title=Laughing When it Hurts: Humor and Violence in the Lives of Costa Rican Prostitutes|journal= [[Women's Studies International Forum]] |date=2 January 1999 |volume=22 |issue=1 |pages=63–78 |doi=10.1016/s0277-5395(98)00109-5}}</ref>
Police officials have expressed a dislike of prostitutes, and are, according to the accounts of some prostitutes, guilty of committing acts of violence, discrimination, and harassment towards prostitutes themselves. Examples of this include rape, false accusations, disinterest in complaints about abuse, and illegal detention.<ref name="Hurts" />
==Transsexual prostitutes==
[[File:Work areas of trans women prostitutes in San José, Costa Rica.svg|thumb|Work areas of trans women prostitutes in the year 2016, in San José, Costa Rica (in red)]]
According to "Transvida", an organisation which is dedicated to defend the rights of the transsexual population, [[Trans woman|trans women]] who are sex workers in San José, mostly work in 2 defined areas, in 2016. One of those areas centers around "Parque Morazán" and the [[Costa Rica Institute of Technology]] and the other one around the "Ministry Of Public Works & Transport" and the [[Hospital Clínica Bíblica]].<ref name="Trans-abuse">{{cite news |url=http://vincentverheyen.com/node/32 |title=Transsexuals deal with stones and bullets when they offer sex - Transsexuals report an increase of attacks in the streets of San José [Costa Rica] & 14 police officers accused of abusing authority against trans women |publication-date=28 June 2016 |others=Translated by Vincent Verheyen (source: La Nación) |access-date=24 July 2016}}</ref>
In June 2016, transwomen who are sex workers in San José have denounced insults and violence (such as attacks involving stones and [[BB gun]] pellets) committed against them, in a local newspaper. The newspaper article included pictures showing multiple BB gun injuries (pellets penetrated inside the bodies), as well as video interviews with the trans women sex workers.<ref name="Trans-abuse" />
In another newspaper article, which appeared in the same edition of the newspaper, it was made clear that, since 2015, there had also been 14 complaints filed with the [[Judicial Investigation Department]] against officers for abusing their authority against trans women. Twelve of those accusations were against officials of the "Fuerza Pública" (an policing instance); one against the Judicial Investigation Department; and one against the municipal police.<ref name="Trans-abuse" />
== HIV/AIDS == An estimated 13,800 people were living with [[HIV/AIDS]] in Costa Rica in 2016.<ref name="unaids16">{{cite web|title=Costa Rica 2016 Country Factsheet|url=http://www.unaids.org/en/regionscountries/countries/costarica/|website=UNAIDS|accessdate=12 April 2018|language=en}}</ref> Traditionally, tourism has been cited as a contributor to the spread of HIV, and other such [[Sexually transmitted disease]]s. Research has linked sex tourism to the transmission of HIV between worker and client.<ref>{{cite journal | last1=Romero-Daza |first1=Nancy |first2=Andrea |last2=Freidus |title=Female Tourists, Casual Sex, and HIV Risk in Costa Rica |journal=Qual Sociol |date=27 March 2008 |issue=31 |pages=169–187 |doi=10.1007/s11133-008-9096-y |volume=31}}</ref> Teenagers and young adults are the most at risk for infection; presently, people ages 15 to 24 account for over 10% of the number of HIV infected individuals living in Costa Rica.<ref name=Cuidate>{{cite journal |last=Freidus |first=Andrea |title=Cuidate: Tourism, drugs, sex and HIV among young people in Monteverde, Costa Rica |journal=University of South Florida Scholar Commons |date=1 June 2005 |pages=1–118|url=http://scholarcommons.usf.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=3882&context=etd |accessdate=17 October 2012}}</ref>
=== HIV/AIDS awareness programs === Since the diagnosis of the first case of HIV in Costa Rica in 1984, the country has run aggressive HIV/AIDS awareness programs. In addition to this, the government has fought to reduce the cost of drugs needed to treat HIV/AIDS patients; since 2003, the government has purchased generic drugs for a much lower cost than other, brand-name drugs.<ref>{{cite web | last=Rosenblum| first=Daniel| title=A Ray Of Hope: Costa Rica's Progressive Approach to HIV/AIDS| url=http://www.umich.edu/~historyj/pages_folder/articles/A_Ray_of_Hope.pdf| publisher=University of Michigan| accessdate=17 October 2012}}</ref> The Roman Catholic Church, however, has opposed the Costa Rican Ministry of Public Health’s efforts to institute HIV prevention and sex education programs. The Church believes that married couples are not at risk for infection because adultery is prohibited. In addition, they feel that the campaign for increased condom use and sex education programs interfere with “Divine Rule.”<ref name="Cuidate" />
=== Perceptions of prostitutes === Prostitutes often associate HIV/AIDS infection with violent behavior. The prostitutes interviewed showed a unique and incorrect understanding of HIV/AIDS, in that it was inextricably linked to violence. Prostitutes see violent men as potential sources of infection, by HIV as well as other diseases such as hepatitis.<ref>{{cite journal | last=Downe |first=Pamela |title=Constructing a Complex of Contagion: The Perceptions of AIDS among Working Prostitutes in Costa Rica|subscription=yes|journal=Social Science & Medicine |date=May 1997 |volume=44 |issue=10 |pages=1575–1583 |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0277953696003899 |accessdate=17 October 2012 |doi=10.1016/S0277-9536(96)00389-9}}</ref>
== Illegal activities == While sex tourism is embraced in Costa Rica due to its economic benefits, there are limits to what is considered lawful conduct. Sex trafficking and child prostitution are problems resulting from the rapid expansion of the sex tourism industry that the Costa Rican government has sought to remedy.<ref name="Underground" /><ref name=Child>{{cite news | last=Mayedo| first=Isabel| title=The child prostitutes of Costa Rica| url=http://www.theprisma.co.uk/2012/03/04/the-child-prostitutes-of-costa-rica/| accessdate=17 October 2012| newspaper=The prisma| date=4 March 2012}}</ref> Recently, the Costa Rican government announced the approval of legislation by congress that would increase penalties for trafficking and related activities. The law also creates a fund designed to combat human trafficking. Minister of the Presidency, Carlos Ricardo Benavides, asserted that "Costa Rica sets a good example" though the implementation of this law, and that human trafficking "must be fought by all possible means."<ref>{{cite news | title=Costa Rica Passes Law Increasing Punishment for Sexual Tourism and Human Trafficking| url=http://thecostaricanews.com/costa-rica-passes-law-increasing-punishment-for-sexual-tourism-and-human-trafficking/13488| accessdate=17 October 2012| newspaper=The Costa Rica News| date=10 October 2012}}</ref>
=== Child prostitution === Costa Rica is a destination for [[child sex tourism]], even though the main source of clients was local, as reported by Tapiana Tregar, CEO of Fundacion Procal (a local NGO attempting to prevent and treat violence against women and children) in a 2000 article. In the same article, Bruce Harris, regional director of Casa Alianza (the Latin American branch of international child care agency Covenant House) said that; even though child prostitution was identified across [[Central America]], the problem seemed to be more "out of control" in Costa Rica. Exact numbers of the children involved were unknown at the time, and the government of Costa Rica had not gathered detailed statistics.<ref> [https://www.motherjones.com/news/feature/2000/10/costarica.html Innocence for Sale] ''Mother Jones'' 2000-10-10.</ref>
Costa Rican Congresswoman Gloria Bejerano cites globalization as one of the factors halting attempts to cease child prostitution, as access to communication and media technologies is widespread. While production and distribution of child pornography is a punishable offense, possession of such materials is not.<ref name="Child" />
The sexual exploitation of children is a significant issue in Costa Rica, and has drawn the attention of the public. Many sex tourists prefer to target children, believing that they are less likely to be infected with HIV. However, children are more susceptible to HIV infection than other age groups. The governmental organization Alianza por tus Derechos (“Alliance for your rights”) pushes for the implementation of new, harsher laws to coincide with the heinousness of the crimes being committed. Very few instances of child prostitution are actually reported to authorities due to the poor categorization of these crimes in legislation.<ref name="Attractions" /><ref name="Child" /> Since 2004 the government and the tourism industry have implemented several initiatives to curb child prostitution, including education campaigns among tourist industry workers to report any illicit activity regarding minors.<ref name=Wright/> Anyone convicted of buying sex from a minor can suffer prison terms of up to 10 years.<ref name=WPCosta />
Child prostitution is widespread. [[Street children]] in the urban areas of San José, [[Puerto Limón|Limon]], and [[Puntarenas]] are particularly at risk.<ref name="US state"/> Costa Rica is a transit and destination point for minors and women trafficked most often for commercial sexual exploitation. Most trafficking victims originate from Colombia, the Dominican Republic, Nicaragua, and [[Guatemala]].<ref name="US state"/>
Since 2004, the government and the tourism industry have implemented several initiatives to curb child prostitution, including education campaigns among tourist industry workers to report any illicit activity regarding minors.<ref name=Wright/> Anyone convicted of buying sex from a minor can suffer a prison term of up to 10 years.<ref name=WPCosta/>
Despite attempts by Costa Rican authorities to improve the situation in Costa Rica, their efforts have had little to no effect. Such efforts were the Law Against Organized Crime in 2009, and the Law for Protection of Victims and Witnesses in 2010. Immigration and the District Attorney’s office assert that efforts thus far have been inadequate, as there have only been two human trafficking cases ending in a strict sentence since the passing of these laws. Lawmakers have since redoubled their efforts, unanimously approving the Law Against Human Trafficking, which would raise the maximum penalty of human trafficking to 16 years.<ref name="Stand">{{cite news|title=Human Trafficking Continues in Costa Rica, as Lawmakers Take a Stand|url=http://insidecostarica.com/2012/10/01/human-trafficking-continues-in-costa-rica-as-lawmakers-take-a-stand/|accessdate=17 October 2012|newspaper=Inside Costa Rica|date=1 October 2012}}</ref>
Children find themselves involved in the sex trade through a number of different circumstances: families seeking a better life for their children are tricked by offers from pimps, who later abuse and drug the children to the point of submissiveness, or they can be sold into the trade by neighbors, relatives, or people they considered friends. Abandoned and afraid, these children seldom find their way back home, and the ones who do are usually ostracized from society.<ref name="Attractions" /> In 2016, the phenomenon of fathers "renting" their daughters as child prostitutes has been called common in [[Limón Province]], but occurred throughout the country. The Ministry of Health of Costa Rica regretted that some citizens of Costa Rica do not denounce this practice.<ref>{{cite news | last = Mata | first = Esteban | date = 26 July 2016 | title = Niñas son ‘alquiladas’ con fines sexuales por sus padres | url = http://www.nacion.com/nacional/politica/Ninas-alquiladas-fines-sexuales-padres_0_1575242475.html | newspaper = La Nación | access-date = 26 July 2016 }}</ref>
=== Sex trafficking === {{see also|Human trafficking in Costa Rica}} According to the 2017 Costa Rica Trafficking in Persons Report, “Costa Rica is a source, transit, and destination country for women and children subjected to sex trafficking.”<ref name="state17">{{cite web|title=Costa Rica 2017 Trafficking in Persons Report|url=https://www.state.gov/j/tip/rls/tiprpt/countries/2017/271170.htm|website=U.S. Department of State|accessdate=12 April 2018}}</ref> Trafficking victims from other countries sometimes pass through Costa Rica on their way to other destinations in Central and South America. Girls are trafficked from Costa Rica to work as prostitutes in the [[United States]], [[Canada]], and [[Europe]]. High profits contribute to human trafficking being an enduring problem. In some cases, earnings of up to $10,000 have been reported for a single trafficking victim. With an estimated 25 to 40 people being trafficked into and out of Costa Rica per week, human trafficking is a large source of revenue.<ref>{{cite web | title=Costa Rica [PDF download]| url=http://www.protectionproject.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/09/Costa-Rica.pdf| publisher=The Protection Project| accessdate=17 October 2012}}</ref> Minors and women trafficked most often for commercial sexual exploitation, and most trafficking victims originate from Colombia, Dominican Republic, Nicaragua and Guatemala.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2008/wha/119154.htm| title=2008 Human Rights Report: Costa Rica| date=2009-02-25| website=Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor| publisher=U.S. Department of State| accessdate=2012-12-13}}</ref>
In the past few years, 76 victims of human trafficking operations have been rescued in Costa Rica. However, it is nearly impossible to know just how many victims of human trafficking there are in the country. For each person rescued from a human trafficking operation, there are at least 20 cases that go unreported, according to Costa Rican immigration authorities. This estimate places the number of trafficking victims in Costa Rica in the past few years somewhere around 1,500.<ref name="Stand"/>
Despite attempts by Costa Rican authorities to improve the situation in Costa Rica, their efforts have had little to no effect. Such efforts were the "Law Against Organized Crime" in 2009, and the "Law for Protection of Victims and Witnesses" in 2010. Immigration and the district attorney’s office assert that efforts thus far have been inadequate, as there have only been two human trafficking cases ending in a strict sentence since the passing of these laws. Lawmakers have since redoubled their efforts, unanimously approving the Law Against Human Trafficking, which would raise the maximum penalty of human trafficking to 16 years.<ref name="Stand" />
The [[United States Department of State]] [[Office to Monitor and Combat Trafficking in Persons]] ranks Costa Rica as a '[[Trafficking in Persons Report#Ranking System|Tier 2]]' country.<ref name="state18">{{cite web |title=Costa Rica 2018 Trafficking in Persons Report |url=https://www.state.gov/j/tip/rls/tiprpt/countries/2018/282637.htm |website=U.S. Department of State |accessdate=26 July 2018}}{{PD-notice}}</ref>
=== International responses === The [[United Nations]] has been an extremely active force in efforts to prevent human trafficking and child sex tourism in Latin American countries. Article 34 of the UN [[Convention on the Rights of the Child]] addresses children’s fundamental right to be protected from sexual exploitation.<ref name=Social>{{cite journal | last=Tepelus| first=Camelia| title=Social responsibility and innovation on trafficking and child sex tourism: Morphing of practice into sustainable tourism policies?| journal=[[Tourism and Hospitality Research]] |date=10 March 2008 |issue=8| pages=98–115| url=http://www.besteducationnetwork.org/?module=file&act=procFileDownload&file_srl=11116&sid=0289f181911280cbeb8139177353b3a4&module_srl=879| accessdate=17 October 2012}}</ref> The CRC was introduced in 1989 and is currently ratified by all but two of the world’s nations. In 2000, an Optional Protocol to the CRC on the Sale of Children, Child Prostitution and Child Pornography was introduced. Many of the articles in the CRC concern the sexual exploitation of children, and the rights of children to be protected from such activities.<ref name="Attractions" />
In 1999, the [[International Labour Organization]] Convention coordinated massive efforts to eradicate many forms of child labor, including the sale and [[trafficking of children]], as well as the sexual exploitation of children for pornography or prostitution.<ref name="Attractions" />
Many countries sought to strengthen existing laws regarding the exploitation of children. Facing pressure from various child welfare groups, the United States passed the [[PROTECT Act]] in April 2003. The act made it illegal for U.S. citizens to travel to another country to have sex, or to conspire to have sex, with a minor. The law also raised the maximum sentence of individuals who either engaged in, or attempted to engage in, sex with a minor to 30 years.
Since 2004, [[World Vision]], a Christian [[humanitarian organization]] operating in nearly 100 countries, has run a campaign to prevent child sex tourism, and to raise awareness of legislation regarding child sex tourism. Under the slogan “‘Abuse a child in this country, go to jail in yours,’” World Vision launched a campaign to deter child sex tourists in Cambodia, Thailand, Costa Rica, Mexico, and Brazil.<ref name="Social" /> The campaign, termed the Child Sex Tourism Prevention Project, was conducted in cooperation with various U.S. government agencies. The project sought to deter sex tourists through various in-flight advertisements and brochure, billboard, and other media warning sex tourists that they are subject to prosecution.<ref name="Attractions" />
Also in 2004, the [[World Tourism Organization]] (WTO), in conjunction with [[ECPAT]] and [[UNICEF]], headed an effort to encourage American travel agencies to abide by a code of conduct. Under the code, hotel and travel companies commit to establishing a policy against commercial sexual exploitation of children.<ref name="Attractions" />

{{Infobox medical condition | Name = Substance-related disorder | Image = | Caption = | DiseasesDB = | ICD10 = F10-F19 | ICD9 = {{ICD9|291}}-{{ICD9|292}}; {{ICD9|303}}–{{ICD9|305}} | ICDO = | OMIM = | MedlinePlus = | eMedicineSubj = | eMedicineTopic = | MeshID = D019966 }}
'''Substance abuse''', also known as '''drug abuse''', is a patterned use of a substance (drug) in which the user consumes the substance in amounts or with methods which are harmful to themselves or others. The drugs used are often associated with levels of intoxication that alter judgment, perception, attention and physical control, not related with medical effects. It is often thought that the main abused substances are illegal drugs and alcohol; however it is becoming more common that prescription drugs and tobacco are a prevalent problem.<ref>{{cite web|title=Substance Abuse and Addiction Health Center |url= http://www.webmd.com/mental-health/addiction/substance-abuse | date=2014-04-22}}</ref>
'''Substance-related disorders''', including both substance dependence and substance abuse, can lead to large societal problems. It is found to be greatest in individuals ages 18–25, with a higher likelihood occurring in men compared to women, and urban residents compared to rural residents. On average, general medical facilities hold 20% of patients with substance-related disorders, possibly leading to psychiatric disorders later on. Over 50% of individuals with substance-related disorders will often have a "dual diagnosis," where they are diagnosed with the substance abuse, as well as a psychiatric diagnosis, the most common being major depression, personality disorder, anxiety disorders, and dysthymia.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Leikin|first=J.B.|title=Substance-Related Disorders in Adults|journal=Disease-a-month|year=2007|volume=53|issue=6|pages=313–335|doi=10.1016/j.disamonth.2007.04.001}}</ref>
==Signs and symptoms==
Common symptoms include: * Sudden changes in behaviour – may engage in secretive or suspicious behaviour * Mood changes – anger towards others, paranoia and little care shown about themselves or their future * Problems with work or school – lack of attendance * Changes in eating and sleeping habits * Changes in friendship groups and poor family relationships * A sudden unexplained change in financial needs – leading to borrowing/stealing money
There are many more symptoms such as physical and psychological changes, though this is often dependent on which drug is being abused. It is, however, common that abusers will experience unpleasant withdrawal symptoms if the drug is taken away from them.<ref>{{cite web |title=Drug Abuse and Dependence Symptoms| url= http://www.webmd.com/mental-health/addiction/tc/drug-abuse-and-dependence-symptoms|accessdate= April 17, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = Drug Abuse and Addiction | url = http://www.helpguide.org/articles/addiction/drug-abuse-and-addiction.htm |accessdate = April 17, 2015}}</ref>
It is also reported that others have strong cravings even after they have not used the drug for a long period of time. This is called being "clean". To determine how the brain triggers these cravings, multiple tests have been done on mice.<ref>{{cite news|last=Aldhous|first=Peter|title='Drug binge' mice reveal why cravings linger|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn13630-drug-binge-mice-reveal-why-cravings-linger.html|accessdate=2011-10-08|newspaper=Newscientist|date=2008-04-09}}</ref> It is also now thought that these cravings can be explained by substance-related disorders as a subcategory of personality disorders as classified by the DSM-5.<ref>{{ cite journal | author = American Psychiatric Publishing | title = Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (Fifth ed.) | date = 2013}}</ref>
==Classification and terminology==
Substance-related disorders were originally subcategorized into "[[substance use disorder]]s" (SUD) and "substance-induced disorders" (SID).<ref>{{DorlandsDict|nine/100010056|substance-related disorders}}</ref><ref name="GalanterKleber2008">{{cite book|author1=Marc Galanter|author2=Herbert D. Kleber|title=The American Psychiatric Publishing textbook of substance abuse treatment|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6wdJgejlQzYC&pg=PA59|accessdate=23 April 2010|year=2008|publisher=American Psychiatric Pub|isbn=978-1-58562-276-4|pages=59}}</ref> Though [[DSM-IV]] makes a firm distinction between the two, SIDs often occur in the context of SUDs.<ref name="FirstFrances2004">{{cite book|author1=Michael B. First|author2=Allen Frances|author3=Harold Alan Pincus|title=DSM-IV-TR guidebook|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hU_L1KUsNfIC&pg=PA123|accessdate=23 April 2010|year=2004|publisher=American Psychiatric Pub|isbn=978-1-58562-068-5|pages=123–}}</ref>
===Substance-induced disorders===
Substance-induced disorders include medical conditions that can be directly attributed to the use of a substance.<ref>{{DorlandsDict|nine/100010072|Substance-induced disorders}}</ref> These conditions include [[Substance intoxication|intoxication]], [[Drug withdrawal|withdrawal]], [[substance-induced delirium]], [[substance-induced psychosis]], and [[substance-induced mood disorder]]s.<ref name="Shaner2000">{{cite book|author=Roderick Shaner|title=Psychiatry|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JxYg4ON0CsMC&pg=RA1-PA85|accessdate=23 April 2010|date=1 April 2000|publisher=Lippincott Williams & Wilkins|isbn=978-0-683-30766-5|pages=1–}}</ref>
===Substance use disorders=== {{Main|Substance use disorder}}
Substance use disorders include substance abuse and [[substance dependence]].<ref>{{DorlandsDict|nine/100010058|Substance use disorders}}</ref> In DSM-IV, the conditions are formally diagnosed as one or the other, but it has been proposed that [[DSM-V]] combine the two into a single condition called "Substance-use disorder".<ref name="urlProposed Revision | APA DSM-5">{{cite web |url=http://www.dsm5.org/ProposedRevisions/Pages/proposedrevision.aspx?rid=431# |title=Proposed Revision | APA DSM-5 |format= |work= |accessdate=2010-04-23}}</ref>
===Changes in Classification===
The more recently published [[DSM-5]] combined substance abuse and substance dependence into a single continuum; this is simply known as substance use disorder and requires more presenting symptoms before a diagnosis is made. It also considers each different substance as its own separate disorder, based upon the same basic criteria. It also distinguishes the difference between dependence and addictions as two separate disorders, not to be confused.<ref>{{ cite journal | author = American Psychiatric Publishing | title = Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (Fifth ed. )|url = http://www.dsm5.org/Documents/Substance%20Use%20Disorder%20Fact%20Sheet.pdf | date = 2013}}</ref>
===Potential Complications===
There are many potential complications that can arise due to substance abuse such as severe physiological damage, psychological changes and social changes that are often not desirable.
Physiological damage is often the most obvious, observed as an abnormal condition affecting the body of an organism: For instance, there are several known alcohol-induced diseases (e.g. [[alcoholic hepatitis]], [[alcoholic liver disease]], [[alcoholic cardiomyopathy]].) Substance abuse is also often associated with premature ageing, fertility complications, brain damage and a higher risk of infectious diseases due to a weakened immune system.<ref>{{cite web|last=Baignet |first=Michael | title = Physical complications of substance abuse: what psychiatrists need to know | journal = Current Opinion in Psychiatry | url = http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/452724_2|accessdate=April 17, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| title = Drug Addictions: complications | url = http://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/drug-addiction/basics/complications/con-20020970 |accessdate= April 17, 2015}}</ref>
Long term abuse has been linked to personality changes such as depression, paranoia, anxiety which can be related to psychological disorders. It is often reported that substance abuse coincides with personality disorders, such as [[borderline personality disorder]]. It has also now been linked to severe brain damage leading to an inability to control behaviours, which could explain why many people who abuse substances go on to develop addictions.<ref>{{cite web| title=Drug Abuse and Dependence Symptoms | url= http://www.webmd.com/mental-health/addiction/tc/drug-abuse-and-dependence-symptoms|accessdate=April 17, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Trull |last2= Sher |last3= Minks Brown | last4=Durbin |last5=Burr | title = Borderline personality disorder and substance use disorder: A review and integration | journal = Clinical Psychology Review|year=2000|volume=20|issue=2|pages=235–253| doi=10.1016/s0272-7358(99)00028-8}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Jentsch |first1=j.d. |last2=Taylor |first2 =J. R. | title = impulsivity resulting from frontostriatal dysfunction in drug abuse: implications for the control of behaviour by reward related stimuli | journal = psychopharmacology |year=1999|volume=146|issue=4|pages=373–390|doi=10.1007/pl00005483}}</ref>
Substance abuse is often regarded as negative in society and therefore those who engage in such behaviours can often be subject to social discrimination. The use of many drugs can lead to criminal convictions, whether the drug itself is illegal or abusers use unlawful methods to fund their substances. It is also more likely that someone will partake in criminal or anti-social behaviour when they are under the influence of a drug.<ref>{{cite web|title=Drug Abuse and Dependence Symptoms| url= http://www.webmd.com/mental-health/addiction/tc/drug-abuse-and-dependence-symptoms| date=2014-12-03}}</ref>
==See also== {{col div|colwidth=30em}} *[[Anxiety]] *[[Behavioural sciences]] *[[Chemical dependency]] *[[Major depressive disorder]] *[[Psychological trauma]] *[[Self-medication]] *[[Shared care]] *[[Substance abuse prevention]] *[[Drug rehabilitation]] *[[Dual diagnosis]] {{colend}}

{{Infobox company | name = Sustainalytics | logo = Sustainalytics_logo.png | logo_size = 200 | logo_alt = Sustainalytics logo | logo_caption = | logo_padding = 10 | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = | type = Private | industry = Financial Services | predecessor = Jantzi Research, DSR, Siri Company | founded = 1992 | founder = Michael Jantzi | hq_location_city = Amsterdam | hq_location_country = Netherlands | num_locations = 13 | products = ESG Research & Ratings, Corporate Governance Research & Ratings | num_employees = 350+ | website = [https://www.sustainalytics.com/ Sustainalytics] }}
'''Sustainalytics''' is a company that rates the sustainability of listed companies based on their [[environmental, social and corporate governance]] (ESG) performance.<ref>Hale, J. [https://finance.yahoo.com/news/sustainalytics-does-company-esg-research-100000652.html "How Sustainalytics Does Company ESG Research"], ''[[Yahoo! Finance]]'', 29 September 2016. Retrieved on 22 December 2017</ref> The company was born from a merger between Toronto-based Jantzi Research, which was founded in 1992 by Sustainalytics' current CEO Michael Jantzi, and its European counterpart.<ref>Baldwin, William. [https://www.forbes.com/sites/baldwin/2017/04/03/this-man-will-purify-your-portfolio/#6523abc0280a "This Man Will Purify Your Portfolio"], ''[[Forbes]]'', 3 April 2017. Retrieved on 22 December 2017</ref> In October 2017, the firm had offices in 13 cities around the world and served more than 450 institutional investor clients. <ref>Critchley, Barry. [http://business.financialpost.com/news/fp-street/responsible-investing-will-be-replaced-by-investing-with-no-prefixes "Responsible investing will be replaced by 'investing with no prefixes'"], ''[[Financial Post]]'', 20 October 2017. Retrieved on 22 December 2017</ref>
== ESG Risk Ratings == On 12 September 2018, Sustainalytics announced the launch of its [[Environmental, social and corporate governance|ESG]] ratings.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.environmental-finance.com/content/news/sustainalytics-launches-gamechanging-esg-risk-ratings.html|title=Sustainalytics Launches ‘Game Changing’ ESG Risk Ratings|last=|first=|date=12 September 2018|website=Environmental Finance|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=13 September 2018}}</ref>
==Morningstar collaboration== In 2016, [[Morningstar, Inc.]] released the first sustainability rating for mutual funds and exchange-traded funds based on Sustainalytics' company ESG research.<ref> [[Morningstar, Inc.]] [https://newsroom.morningstar.com/newsroom/news-archive/press-release-details/2016/Morningstar-Introduces-Industrys-First-Sustainability-Rating-for-20000-Funds-Globally-Giving-Investors-New-Way-to-Evaluate-Investments-Based-on-Environmental-Social-and-Governance-ESG-Factors/default.aspx "Morningstar Introduces Industry’s First Sustainability Rating for 20,000 Funds Globally, Giving Investors New Way to Evaluate Investments Based on Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) Factors"], 1 March 2016. Retrieved on 22 December 2017 </ref> <ref>Zulz, Emily. [http://www.thinkadvisor.com/2016/03/01/morningstar-releases-sustainability-rating-for-200?slreturn=1513934558 "Morningstar Releases Sustainability Rating for 20,000 Funds"] ''Think Adviser'', 1 March 2016, Retrieved on 22 December 2017</ref> In 2017, [[Morningstar, Inc.]] become a 40% shareholder in the company alongside senior management, [[Stichting Pensioenfonds Zorg en Welzijn]] (PGGM), [[ABN AMRO Group]] and Renewable Partners <ref>Sustainalytics [https://www.sustainalytics.com/press-release/morningstar-acquire-stake-sustainalytics/ "Morningstar and Sustainalytics Expand Their Sustainability Collaboration"], 24 July 2017. Retrieved on 22 December 2017.</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sustainalytics.com/about-us/|title=About Us|last=|first=|date=13 September 2018|website=Sustainalytics|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Yahoo Finance == In 2018, Yahoo Finance started to include Sustainalytics' ESG score for over 2,000 companies.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.barrons.com/articles/yahoo-adds-sustainability-company-data-1517599809|title=Yahoo Adds Sustainability Company Data|last=Norton|first=Leslie P.|access-date=2018-02-12|language=en-US}}</ref> Retail investors will also be able to see if companies are involved in controversies or controversial products or practices, such as thermal coal and controversial weapons.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.barrons.com/articles/yahoo-adds-sustainability-company-data-1517599809|title=Yahoo Adds Sustainability Company Data|last=Norton|first=Leslie P.|access-date=2018-02-12|language=en-US}}</ref>
==Green lending and green bonds== In 2017, [[ING Group]] issued the first sustainability improvement loan where the interest rate of the loan is coupled to the sustainability rating of the lender, [[Koninklijke Philips N.V.]], as measured by Sustainalytics.<ref>[[ING Group.]] [https://www.ing.com/Newsroom/All-news/ING-and-Philips-collaborate-on-sustainable-loan.htm "ING and Philips collaborate on sustainable loan"], 19 April 2017. Retrieved on 22 December 2017</ref> <ref>Woudt, Job. [https://fd.nl/ondernemen/1198136/lening-philips-gekoppeld-aan-duurzaamheid "Lening Philips gekoppeld aan duurzaamheid"], ''[[Het Financieele Dagblad]]'', 19 April 2017. Retrieved on 22 December 2017</ref> Sustainalytics also provides "second opinions" for corporate governmental issuers that assesses the framework of the issuer's green, social or sustainability bond.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gfmag.com/topics/capital-markets-and-corporate-finance/passing-fad-or-future-habit|title=Passing Fad or Future Habit? Green-bond issuances have been growing, even if there’s no precise definition of what a “green bond” is.|last=Mellow|first=Craig|date=|website=Global Finance Magazine|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-02-12}}</ref> In 2017 and 2018, investors voted Sustainalyitcs as the "Most Impressive Second Opinion Provider" for this service in the GlobalCapital Sustainable and Responsible Capital Markets Awards 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.globalcapital.com/article/b14mmqk0gbt9q8/globalcapital-sustainable-and-responsible-capital-markets-awards-2017-the-winners|title=GlobalCapital Sustainable and Responsible Capital Markets Awards 2017: the Winners|last=Hay|first=John|date=|website=www.globalcapital.com|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-02-12}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.globalcapital.com/article/b19tcwdcbrq2ks/sri-award-winners-2018-revealed|title=SRI Award Winners 2018 Revealed|last=|first=|date=5 September 2018|website=Global Capital|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=13 September 2018}}</ref>
==Emissions scandals== Sustainalytics flagged governance concerns at [[Volkswagen]] months before the 2015 [[Volkswagen emissions scandal]].<ref>Kerber, Kerry & Flaherty, Michael. [https://www.reuters.com/article/us-climate-ratings-analysis/investing-with-green-ratings-its-a-gray-area-idUSKBN19H0DM "Investing with 'green' ratings? It's a gray area"], ''[[Reuters]]'', 26 June 2017. Retrieved on 22 December 2017</ref> Sustainalytics had also flagged corporate governance concerns at [[Fiat Automobiles]] 18 months prior to the company being accused of breaking emissions laws in 104,000 diesel vehicles in January 2017 <ref>Mooney, Attracta. [https://www.ft.com/content/c40dd7fa-0ba4-11e6-b0f1-61f222853ff3 "When markets ignore vital warning signs"], ''[[Financial Times]]'', 8 May 2016. Retrieved on 22 December 2017</ref>
==HBR's 100 best performing CEOs== In 2015, [[Harvard Business Review]] started to include Sustainalytics' ESG Rating as part of its assessment of the 100 best performing CEOs in the world.<ref>Loudenback, Tanza. [https://www.businessinsider.com.au/the-25-best-performing-ceos-in-the-world-2015-10 "The 25 best-performing CEOs in the world, according to the Harvard Business Review"], ''[[Business Insider]]'', 13 October 2015. Retrieved on 22 December 2017</ref>
==Indices== In 2000, Sustainalytics launched the [[Jantzi Social Index]], the first socially-screened stock index composed of Canadian companies, and, in 2013, Sustainalytics partnered with the United Nation's [[United Nations Global Compact|Global Compact]] to launch the Global Compact 100 index, a real-time stock index that tracks Global Compact signatories awarded a high [[Environmental, social and corporate governance|ESG]] rating by Sustainalytics.<ref>Murray, Sarah. [https://www.ft.com/content/e4a0691e-f7ec-11e4-8bd5-00144feab7de "Sustainability measurement: index looks to connect investors {GATED CONTENT}"], ''[[Financial Times]]'', 2 June 2015. Retrieved on 22 December 2017</ref> <ref>Power, Gavin. [https://www.unglobalcompact.org/take-action/action/global-compact-100 "Global Compact 100"], ''[[United Nations Global Compact]]'' Retrieved on 22 December 2017</ref> On 10 September 2018, the [[World Bank]] issued a sustainable development note linked to Sustainalytics' Global Sustainability Signatories Index, another index that tracks [[United Nations Global Compact]] signatories with high sustainability ratings.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/20d0b294-b4d3-11e8-b3ef-799c8613f4a1|title=UBS launches World Bank sustainable debt product|last=Martin|first=Katie|date=10 September 2018|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=13 September 2018}}</ref> The note will not pay a coupon, but rather return the principle in addition to the positive return of the index.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sustainalytics.com/global-sustainability-signatories-index/|title=Global Sustainability Signatories Index 7.5% VC ER|last=|first=|date=10 September 2018|website=www.sustainalytics.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=13 September 2018}}</ref>
